Modern B2B marketing requires sophisticated technology: marketing automation platforms (HubSpot, Marketo, Pardot), advanced CRM utilization, marketing analytics, SEO/content management tools, account-based marketing platforms, webinar technology, and email marketing systems. Assessment suggests EWM Global operates with basic CRM (likely under-utilized) and minimal marketing technology investment.

This creates massive inefficiency: manual lead follow-up, inability to nurture prospects systematically, no lead scoring or qualification automation, limited ability to run multi-touch campaigns, and no systematic measurement. For comparison, B2B companies at $20M+ revenue typically invest $50K-$150K annually in marketing technology and see 3:1 to 5:1 ROI through improved conversion rates and sales efficiency (Chief Martec State of MarTech Survey). The gap between your current state and required state is likely 2-3 years of technology infrastructure development.

5. Strong Foundation with Service Quality, But Hidden from Market

Not everything is problematic. Your Customer Effort Score of 4/5 indicates clients find you relatively easy to work with—a significant competitive advantage if properly leveraged. Your 24-year operational track record provides credibility. Your specialized focus on complex deferred compensation and carry/coinvestment plans (69% + 30% = 99% of revenue) positions you as a specialist rather than generalist. These are valuable marketing assets currently under-leveraged.

The opportunity: Transform service quality and specialization into compelling market positioning, case studies, customer testimonials, thought leadership content, and differentiated messaging. Companies that systematically convert operational strengths into marketing assets see 20-35% improvement in win rates and 15-25% reduction in sales cycle length (SiriusDecisions B2B Content Research). You have the raw materials for strong marketing—they're just not being packaged, communicated, or amplified to the market.

Marketing Investment Benchmark Analysis

Typical B2B SaaS/Fintech Marketing Investment: 15-25% of revenue (growth stage)
EWM Global Revenue: $24M annually
Expected Marketing Budget Range: $3.6M-$6M annually (15-25%)
Conservative Estimate for Established Company: $2.4M-$3.6M (10-15% given 24-year stability)
EWM Global Current Investment (estimated): $500K-$1M (~2-4% of revenue)
Investment Gap: $1.4M-$2.6M under-invested annually

Assessment Basis: Given marketing score of 50/100, minimal digital presence, limited marketing team, and relationship-dependent growth model, EWM Global likely invests 2-4% of revenue in marketing vs. industry standard 10-15% for established B2B companies or 15-25% for growth-stage companies. This under-investment explains low market share (10%), weak brand awareness, and reliance on referrals. Competitor Computershare likely invests 8-12% of relevant segment revenue in marketing, creating 3-6x marketing spending advantage.

Key Findings & Strategic Insights

Finding #1: Marketing is Your Primary Growth Constraint

Growth Bottleneck Risk HIGH Marketing score of 50/100 cannot support 20% growth target

Your 20% annual growth target requires adding $4.8M in new revenue—a 4x acceleration from historical performance. Analysis reveals this ambitious goal is fundamentally constrained by marketing capability, not operations, service delivery, or technical capacity. The hard truth: You cannot sell to customers who don't know you exist, and you cannot scale through referrals alone.

The growth mathematics expose the problem:

  • Historical Growth: ~$1M annually over 24 years (4% compound growth)
  • Required New Annual Revenue: $4.8M (20% of $24M base)
  • Estimated Average Client Value: $200K-$400K annually
  • Required New Clients Annually: 12-24 new logo wins
  • Estimated Current Win Rate: 20-30% (based on service quality but weak positioning)
  • Required Qualified Opportunities: 40-120 annually (vs. likely current pipeline of 15-30)
  • Lead Generation Gap: 25-90 additional qualified opportunities needed vs. current state

Relationship-based referral generation cannot consistently produce 40-120 qualified opportunities annually. This requires systematic demand generation: SEO/content marketing driving inbound leads, targeted account-based marketing, strategic partnerships, digital advertising, event marketing, and thought leadership positioning. Your current marketing score of 50/100 indicates these capabilities are absent or severely under-developed.

Strategic Implication: Marketing infrastructure development is not a "nice to have"—it's the critical path to achieving growth targets. Without 18-24 months of focused marketing investment and capability building, the 20% growth target is mathematically unachievable and should be revised to 8-12% (achievable with current relationship-driven model plus moderate marketing enhancement).

Finding #2: NPS of 4 Reveals Hidden Customer Dissatisfaction Undermining Growth

Net Promoter Score 4 Industry benchmark: 30-40+ for B2B fintech

Your Net Promoter Score of just 4 (on a -100 to +100 scale) is a critical finding with direct marketing implications. NPS measures customer loyalty and likelihood to recommend—essentially, it quantifies your referral engine and organic growth potential. An NPS of 4 indicates you have approximately equal numbers of promoters (customers who would actively recommend you) and detractors (customers who would discourage others), with a large group of passives in between.

Why This Matters for Marketing: Companies with NPS below 10 generate 60-80% fewer referrals than those with NPS of 40+ (Bain & Company NPS Research). Given EWM Global's historical dependence on referral-driven growth, this low score means your primary growth engine is broken. You cannot simultaneously depend on word-of-mouth growth AND have minimal customer advocacy—these are incompatible.

The NPS of 4 also reveals deeper issues:

  • Service Quality Gaps: Despite CES of 4/5 (ease of doing business), customers aren't enthusiastic advocates. This suggests "adequate but not exceptional" service.
  • Value Perception Issues: Customers may view EWM Global as expensive or not delivering clear ROI vs. alternatives.
  • Limited Differentiation: If customers can't articulate why EWM Global is superior, they won't recommend you passionately.
  • Communication Gaps: The absence of systematic customer feedback collection means you don't know WHY customers aren't promoting you.
  • Marketing Asset Shortage: Low NPS means limited testimonials, case studies, and referenceable customers—all critical B2B marketing assets.

Marketing Consequence: Your marketing effectiveness is severely constrained by lack of customer advocates. B2B technology purchase decisions are 75% influenced by peer recommendations and customer references (G2 B2B Buyer Behavior Report). With NPS of 4, you have minimal social proof, weak testimonial content, and limited reference-ability—all fundamental to enterprise sales in financial services. Competitors with NPS of 40+ have 8-10x more promoters generating referrals and providing references, creating compounding competitive advantage.

The Link to Marketing Score: Low NPS contributes directly to your 50/100 marketing score because it indicates failed customer marketing (turning customers into advocates), absence of systematic customer feedback driving service improvement, and limited marketing assets (case studies, testimonials, reviews). Companies with strong marketing functions typically achieve NPS scores 20-30 points higher through proactive customer success programs, systematic feedback loops, and customer advocacy initiatives.

Critical Insight: Improving NPS from 4 to 30+ (industry-average) would generate an estimated 15-25 additional qualified referrals annually (based on 85 employee company with ~50-80 client relationships). At 25-35% referral close rates (typically 2-3x higher than cold opportunities), this represents 4-9 additional client wins worth $800K-$3.6M in annual recurring revenue—essentially funding 15-75% of your growth target through improved customer advocacy alone. This makes NPS improvement a top-tier marketing priority with direct ROI.

Finding #3: Weak Positioning and Unclear Differentiation in Crowded Market

Assessment of EWM Global's market positioning reveals a classic "best-kept secret" problem: you have genuine differentiation and specialized expertise, but it's not clearly articulated or consistently communicated to the market. When evaluating your positioning against competitors Computershare, GPx, and HRSoft, the critical differentiators are not immediately evident from external perspective.

Current Positioning Assessment (Inferred):

  • Generic Messaging: Likely positioned as "equity compensation plan administrator" or "deferred compensation services"—functionally accurate but not differentiated
  • Feature-Focused vs. Value-Focused: Probably describes what you do (plan administration, technology platform, compliance support) rather than the business outcomes you deliver
  • Specialist Advantage Under-Communicated: 99% revenue concentration in deferred cash and carry/coinvestment administration is a powerful specialization story not being told
  • Service Quality Advantage Hidden: CES of 4/5 suggests you're easier to work with than competitors, but this isn't leading with this message
  • Target Audience Ambiguity: Unclear if you're targeting PE/VC firms, hedge funds, investment banks, or broader financial services—each requires different positioning

Competitive Positioning Analysis:

Company Likely Positioning Advantages vs. EWM Global EWM Global Counter-Positioning Opportunity
Computershare "Global scale, enterprise reliability, comprehensive platform" Brand recognition, $2B+ corporation credibility, global reach, massive resources "Specialized expertise vs. generalist; partner attention vs. account number; financial services focus vs. broad market"
GPx "Innovative technology, modern platform" Newer technology stack, potentially better UX, growth-company energy "24-year proven track record vs. unproven newcomer; deep regulatory expertise vs. learning curve; established processes"
HRSoft "Flexible technology, customizable solutions" Platform flexibility, potential broader HR capabilities "Deferred comp/carry specialization vs. general HR tool; financial services domain expertise vs. horizontal platform"

Recommended Positioning Direction: "The Specialist's Choice for Complex Deferred Compensation & Carry Administration in Financial Services." This positioning leverages your concentration (99% in deferred cash + carry/coinvest), targets your core market (financial services), emphasizes complexity/expertise (vs. commoditized equity), and implies deep specialization vs. generalist competitors. However, this is just strategic direction—effective positioning requires customer research, message testing, and systematic deployment across all marketing channels.

Marketing Impact: Weak positioning reduces marketing efficiency by 40-60% because messaging doesn't resonate, differentiation isn't clear, and prospects default to "safe choice" (largest vendor) or price comparison (commoditization). Companies with strong positioning achieve 25-35% higher win rates and 15-20% price premiums because they're selling differentiated value, not commoditized services (April Dunford positioning research).

Finding #4: Digital Marketing Capabilities 5+ Years Behind Competitive Standard

Assessment of digital marketing maturity reveals EWM Global operates with capabilities typical of 2018-2019, not 2024. This gap creates significant competitive disadvantage as B2B buyer behavior has fundamentally shifted to digital-first research and self-service education before engaging vendors.

Digital Marketing Gap Analysis:

  • SEO & Organic Visibility: Likely absent from first-page Google results for key terms like "deferred compensation plan administrator," "carry plan administration," or "Section 409A administration services"—meaning you're invisible when prospects search
  • Content Marketing: Minimal educational content (blog posts, whitepapers, guides, webinars) demonstrating expertise in IRS 409A compliance, ERISA fiduciary obligations, or carry plan structures
  • Marketing Automation: No systematic lead nurturing, drip campaigns, or behavioral-based email marketing to stay engaged with prospects over 6-18 month sales cycles
  • Account-Based Marketing (ABM): No targeted campaigns for specific high-value prospects (e.g., top 50 PE firms, specific hedge funds, investment banks)
  • Analytics & Attribution: Cannot track customer journey from first touch to close; no visibility into which marketing activities generate pipeline
  • Paid Digital Advertising: Limited or no presence in Google Ads, LinkedIn advertising, or industry publication advertising
  • Social Media Presence: Minimal thought leadership on LinkedIn, no consistent executive visibility or company brand building
  • Review & Social Proof: Limited presence on G2, Capterra, or industry review sites that B2B buyers consult

B2B Buyer Behavior Context: Gartner research shows that B2B buyers complete 60-70% of purchase journey before engaging sales—they're researching online, reading content, comparing vendors, and forming opinions. If EWM Global isn't present in this digital research phase, you're eliminated from consideration before you know the opportunity exists. Your competitors are appearing in search results, publishing thought leadership, running targeted LinkedIn ads, and capturing leads you never see.

Digital Presence Scorecard (Estimated)
Website Quality & Conversion Optimization 2/5 -3 points vs. benchmark
SEO & Organic Search Visibility 1.5/5 -3.5 points vs. benchmark
Content Marketing & Thought Leadership 2/5 -2.5 points vs. benchmark
Marketing Automation & Lead Nurturing 1.5/5 -3 points vs. benchmark
Paid Digital Advertising (Google, LinkedIn) 1/5 -3 points vs. benchmark
Social Media & Executive Thought Leadership 2/5 -2.5 points vs. benchmark
Marketing Analytics & Attribution 1/5 -3.5 points vs. benchmark
Overall Digital Marketing Maturity 1.6/5 (32%) Level 1-2: Initial/Developing

Benchmark: B2B fintech companies at $20M+ revenue achieving 15-20% growth typically score 4.0-4.5/5 across digital marketing capabilities (Marketing Benchmark Report, Momentum ITSMA).

Competitive Consequence: Computershare has professional digital marketing with SEO-optimized content, paid advertising, marketing automation, and sophisticated analytics. When financial services companies search for plan administration solutions, Computershare dominates search results and captures leads EWM Global never sees. This digital disadvantage compounds over time—Computershare builds SEO authority, content libraries, and lead databases while EWM Global remains dependent on reactive referrals. The gap widens unless addressed systematically.

Investment to Close Gap: Building competitive digital marketing capability requires 18-24 months and $400K-$800K investment: website redesign, SEO/content program, marketing automation platform, paid digital advertising, analytics infrastructure, and specialized digital marketing talent. However, this investment generates measurable ROI—companies that build comprehensive digital marketing see 3:1 to 5:1 return through reduced customer acquisition cost and increased lead volume (HubSpot State of Inbound Marketing).

Finding #5: Significant Untapped Opportunity in Customer Marketing & Expansion

While new customer acquisition receives most attention, analysis reveals EWM Global has substantial untapped revenue potential within the existing customer base through systematic customer marketing. With an estimated 50-80 client relationships generating $24M revenue ($300K-$480K average client value), there are multiple expansion vectors currently under-leveraged.

Customer Marketing Opportunity Analysis:

  • Cross-Sell Opportunity: Clients using only deferred cash plans (69% of revenue) could be introduced to carry/coinvestment administration (30% of revenue) or vice versa. If 30-40% of clients use only one service line, cross-sell potential is $2M-$4M.
  • Plan Participant Growth: As client companies grow, plan participation expands—but EWM Global likely isn't systematically tracking or celebrating growth milestones with clients.
  • Service Tier Upgrade: Clients on basic service tiers could be offered premium support, enhanced reporting, consulting services, or white-glove service—15-25% typically upgrade when offered.
  • Referral Generation: With NPS of 4, you're not systematically activating satisfied clients to provide referrals, introductions, or testimonials—massive missed opportunity.
  • Client Advisory Board: No formal mechanism for engaging top clients in product development, creating deeper relationships and retention.
  • Educational Programs: Clients face evolving IRS 409A regulations, DOL guidance, and plan design trends—educational webinars, guides, and consulting could add value and revenue.

Financial Impact of Customer Marketing: Research from Bain & Company shows that a 5% improvement in customer retention increases profits by 25-95% in service businesses. For EWM Global with $24M revenue, improving retention from estimated 90% to 95% (industry-leading) would retain an additional $1.2M annually. Combined with 10-15% expansion revenue from cross-sell and upsell, customer marketing could contribute $2-4M toward your $4.8M growth target—essentially funding 40-80% of required growth from existing relationships.

Strategic Insight: Customer marketing is the fastest path to revenue growth with lowest customer acquisition cost (CAC). While new logo acquisition might have CAC of $50K-$100K per client (sales cycles of 6-12 months), expansion revenue from existing clients has CAC of $5K-$15K and cycles of 1-3 months. A balanced growth strategy allocates 40-50% of marketing resources to customer marketing (retention, expansion, advocacy) vs. 100% focus on new acquisition. This approach accelerates growth while improving unit economics.

Required Capabilities: Effective customer marketing requires: (1) Systematic customer segmentation and expansion tracking; (2) Customer success programs with health scoring and proactive intervention; (3) Regular business reviews highlighting value delivered and identifying expansion opportunities; (4) Customer advocacy programs generating referrals and testimonials; (5) Educational content and community building; (6) Net Promoter Score feedback loops driving continuous improvement. Current state assessment suggests these capabilities are absent or informal—building them is a 12-18 month initiative but generates immediate ROI.

Marketing Strengths & Weaknesses

💪 Marketing Strengths

1. Strong Operational Foundation Providing Marketing Raw Materials

EWM Global's 24-year track record, specialized expertise in complex deferred compensation and carry/coinvestment administration, and Customer Effort Score of 4/5 provide substantial marketing assets. You have:

  • Deep domain expertise in IRS Section 409A compliance, ERISA regulations, and securities administration
  • Proven operational reliability serving financial services institutions with mission-critical plan administration
  • Long-tenured employees (typical of 24-year companies) with deep client relationships
  • Successful client implementations that could be converted to case studies and testimonials
  • Specialized knowledge that can be packaged into thought leadership content

Why This Matters: Many marketing challenges stem from lack of product-market fit or service quality issues. EWM Global's 24-year survival and $24M revenue base indicate you've solved the "what to sell and how to deliver it" problem. Your challenge is purely marketing execution—getting the story told, reaching the right audience, and converting interest to revenue. This is far easier to fix than fundamental product or service problems.

How to Leverage: Conduct customer interviews to develop 6-10 detailed case studies highlighting specific client challenges, EWM Global solutions, and quantified business outcomes. Convert this customer success content into the foundation of your marketing—website, sales presentations, proposals, and content marketing. Companies with strong case study libraries see 20-30% higher close rates in B2B sales.

2. Specialized Market Position with Clear Target Audience

EWM Global's 99% revenue concentration in deferred cash and carry/coinvestment plan administration (vs. only 1% in broader equity compensation) represents a powerful specialization advantage if properly positioned. You serve a specific niche—financial services firms (PE, VC, hedge funds, investment banks) with complex deferred compensation and carry structures—rather than competing in the commoditized general equity compensation market.

Why This Matters: Specialists command 15-25% price premiums over generalists, face less price competition, and win deals at 20-30% higher rates because they're selling expertise, not commoditized services (Hinge Research Institute professional services marketing study). Your focus on complex financial services clients is a significant competitive advantage vs. Computershare's broad horizontal platform or HRSoft's general HR focus.

How to Leverage: Develop razor-sharp positioning around "The specialist in complex deferred compensation and carry administration for financial services firms." Target all marketing exclusively to this audience—PE/VC firms with coinvest programs, hedge funds with deferred comp plans, investment banks with carry arrangements. Build content, SEO, and thought leadership around specialized topics: 409A compliance for hedge funds, carry plan design for PE firms, ERISA considerations for coinvestment vehicles. Specialization makes marketing far more efficient by narrowing focus.

3. Established Client Base Providing Stability for Marketing Investment

With $24M in annual recurring revenue from plan administration services, EWM Global has a stable financial foundation to invest in marketing infrastructure. Unlike early-stage startups burning cash to find product-market fit, you have proven demand, predictable revenue, and financial capacity to make multi-year marketing investments. Your 15% growth last year demonstrates the business model works—you're optimizing and scaling, not searching for viability.

Why This Matters: Marketing transformation requires sustained investment over 18-24 months before full results materialize—SEO takes 6-12 months to gain traction, brand awareness builds gradually, content libraries grow over time, and marketing automation requires lead volume to optimize. Companies with unstable revenue cannot sustain this investment timeline. EWM Global's $24M recurring base provides the luxury of patient capital for marketing development.

How to Leverage: Commit to a 3-year marketing transformation plan with appropriate budget ($1.5M-$2.5M annually, growing from current ~$500K-$1M). Structure investment as percentage of revenue (6-10%) to scale with growth. Focus on building durable marketing assets—SEO authority, content libraries, brand awareness, marketing infrastructure—rather than short-term tactical campaigns. Companies that make sustained marketing investments see compounding returns in years 2-3 as assets accumulate.

4. Low Current Market Share (10%) = Significant White Space Opportunity

While 10% market share might appear weak, it actually represents substantial growth headroom. The equity compensation administration market is large and fragmented, with no single player dominating (even Computershare holds 20-30% at most). Your low share means you can grow significantly without triggering intense competitive response or market saturation.

Why This Matters: Companies with sub-15% market share can typically achieve 20-30% annual growth for 5+ years simply by taking share from competitors and capturing new market entrants (McKinsey Market Share Growth Analysis). You don't need to create new market demand—you need to win deals that competitors are currently winning. This is largely a marketing and sales execution challenge, not a market opportunity question.

How to Leverage: Position growth strategy around "capturing unfair share of new plan implementations." Target prospects currently using competitors (Computershare, GPx, HRSoft) with messaging around specialist expertise, service quality, and competitive service level commitments. Develop competitive battlecards highlighting your advantages. Focus marketing on prospects dissatisfied with current providers—these have 3-5x higher conversion rates than satisfied customers.

⚠️ Critical Marketing Weaknesses

1. No Dedicated Marketing Leadership or Professional Marketing Team

Assessment strongly suggests EWM Global lacks a CMO, VP Marketing, or dedicated marketing leader with strategic responsibility for brand, demand generation, and growth. Marketing activities likely fall to sales leadership, business development, or are handled reactively by administrative staff. With 85 employees and $24M revenue, you're well past the threshold (typically $10-15M) where professional marketing leadership becomes essential.

Why This Is Critical: Without marketing leadership, you have no one accountable for brand positioning, lead generation targets, marketing ROI, or coordinating marketing activities. Marketing happens reactively (responding to RFPs, creating materials when sales asks) rather than proactively driving pipeline. Companies without dedicated marketing leadership grow 40-60% slower than those with professional CMOs/VPs of Marketing (Pacific Crest SaaS Survey).

Competitive Disadvantage: Computershare has a full marketing department with specialists in digital marketing, content creation, events, and brand management. You're bringing unstructured part-time efforts to compete against full-time professionals—it's an unfair fight.

Business Impact: This leadership gap is likely the root cause of your 50/100 marketing score and explains absence of marketing strategy, limited digital presence, and inability to execute sophisticated campaigns. Without a marketing leader, the CEO/founder is probably spending 20-40% of time on ad-hoc marketing activities—time that should be spent on strategy, M&A, or major client relationships. The fully-loaded cost of CEO time on tactical marketing is likely $100K-$150K annually, which could fund a professional Marketing Director.

Remediation Path: Immediate priority: Hire Marketing Director/VP within 90 days. Required profile: 8-12 years B2B marketing experience, preferably in fintech or financial services, with proven demand generation and digital marketing expertise. Salary range: $140K-$180K + bonus for Director-level; $180K-$240K for VP-level in Stamford, CT market. This single hire will increase marketing effectiveness by 200-300% within 12 months.

2. Absence of Systematic Lead Generation and Demand Creation Programs

Current state assessment reveals EWM Global operates with minimal systematic lead generation—no regular inbound marketing, limited outbound campaigns, no account-based marketing programs, and relationship/referral dependence that cannot scale. You're likely capturing 10-20 qualified leads annually vs. the 100-150 needed to support 20% growth.

Why This Is Critical: Referrals and reactive RFP responses generate unpredictable, lumpy pipeline that cannot be forecasted or managed. In months when no referrals materialize, pipeline dries up and sales team has nothing to work. Companies without systematic lead generation experience 40-60% pipeline volatility and miss growth targets 70% of the time (SiriusDecisions Demand Generation Benchmark).

Quantified Gap:

  • Required new clients annually: 12-24 (to achieve $4.8M growth at $200K-$400K average client value)
  • Typical B2B fintech close rate: 20-30%
  • Required qualified opportunities: 40-120 annually
  • Current lead generation (estimated): 15-30 leads annually via referrals
  • Lead generation gap: 25-90 additional qualified leads needed

Business Impact: Lead generation gap makes 20% growth target unachievable and forces sales team to spend excessive time prospecting rather than closing deals. Sales productivity is likely 30-40% lower than potential because reps are doing marketing's job (cold outreach, prospecting, lead qualification).

Remediation Path: Build integrated demand generation engine over 12-18 months: (1) SEO and content marketing to generate 30-50 inbound leads annually; (2) Account-based marketing targeting 50-100 named accounts (specific PE firms, hedge funds, investment banks) with personalized campaigns; (3) Strategic partnerships with complementary service providers (law firms, consultants) generating 15-25 referral leads annually; (4) Industry events and webinars generating 20-40 leads annually; (5) LinkedIn advertising targeting CFOs/HR leaders at financial services firms. Combined, these programs can generate 100-150+ qualified leads annually—sufficient to support 20%+ growth.

3. No Marketing Measurement, Analytics, or ROI Tracking

The absence of systematic marketing metrics means EWM Global cannot answer fundamental questions: What's our customer acquisition cost (CAC)? What's the ROI of marketing investments? Which lead sources produce highest-quality opportunities? What's our brand awareness in the target market? How many touches does it take to close a deal? What's marketing's contribution to pipeline?

Why This Is Critical: Without measurement, you cannot optimize marketing spend, prove marketing ROI to leadership, hold marketing accountable for results, or identify what's working vs. wasting money. You're essentially operating marketing on gut feel and anecdotes rather than data-driven decision making. Companies with comprehensive marketing analytics achieve 15-25% better marketing ROI than those without measurement (Forrester Marketing Measurement Benchmark).

Specific Gaps:

  • No lead source tracking (which channels generate opportunities: referrals, web, events, partnerships)
  • No conversion rate measurement by stage (lead → opportunity → customer)
  • No customer acquisition cost (CAC) calculation or tracking over time
  • No marketing-sourced revenue attribution or pipeline contribution analysis
  • No website analytics beyond basic traffic (conversions, engagement, journey analysis missing)
  • No brand awareness tracking or market perception measurement
  • No campaign performance measurement or A/B testing

Business Impact: Marketing likely over-invests in low-performing activities and under-invests in high-performing channels because you lack data to guide resource allocation. You're probably wasting 20-35% of marketing budget on ineffective activities—for a $1M marketing budget, this represents $200K-$350K annually in waste. Additionally, inability to prove marketing ROI constrains marketing budget growth because leadership views it as an expense rather than investment with measurable returns.

Remediation Path: Implement marketing analytics infrastructure within 60-90 days: (1) Deploy marketing automation platform with lead tracking and attribution (HubSpot, Pardot, Marketo - $20K-$40K annually); (2) Implement advanced Google Analytics with goal tracking, custom reports, and journey analysis; (3) Develop marketing dashboard with key metrics: leads by source, conversion rates, CAC, pipeline contribution, marketing-sourced revenue, campaign ROI; (4) Establish monthly marketing business review with standardized reporting to executive team; (5) Create closed-loop reporting connecting marketing activities to revenue outcomes. These capabilities enable data-driven marketing optimization and prove marketing ROI.

4. Minimal Marketing Technology Infrastructure (MarTech Stack)

Assessment indicates EWM Global operates with basic CRM (likely Salesforce or similar) with minimal marketing utilization, no marketing automation, limited email marketing capability, no SEO tools, no social media management platform, and basic website without conversion optimization. This technology gap creates massive manual inefficiency and limits marketing sophistication.

Why This Matters: Modern B2B marketing requires integrated technology: marketing automation (lead nurturing, scoring, email campaigns), CRM marketing features (segmentation, campaign management), SEO tools (keyword research, rank tracking, technical SEO), content management systems (website, blog, resources), social media management (scheduling, monitoring), analytics platforms (website, campaign, attribution), and account-based marketing tools (targeted account programs). Companies with mature MarTech stacks achieve 25-40% better marketing efficiency than those with minimal technology (Chief Martec State of Marketing Technology).

Business Impact: Without marketing automation, lead nurturing is impossible—prospects who aren't ready to buy immediately are lost forever. Manual email campaigns and follow-up require 10-15x more staff time than automated workflows. Inability to track lead behavior and engagement means you cannot prioritize sales follow-up or identify hot prospects. Website lacks conversion optimization, probably converting at 0.5-1% vs. optimized sites at 3-5%—you're losing 60-80% of potential leads due to poor website conversion.

Remediation Path: Build comprehensive MarTech stack over 12 months with $75K-$150K investment: (1) Marketing automation platform (HubSpot Marketing Hub, Marketo, Pardot) - $20K-$50K annually; (2) Website redesign with conversion optimization - $30K-$60K one-time; (3) SEO toolset (Ahrefs, SEMrush, Moz) - $5K-$10K annually; (4) Social media management (Hootsuite, Sprout Social) - $3K-$8K annually; (5) Content management and collaboration tools - $5K-$10K annually; (6) Analytics and reporting platforms - $5K-$15K annually. This technology infrastructure enables sophisticated marketing execution and improves efficiency by 200-300%.

5. Weak Brand Awareness and Market Visibility

With 10% market share and minimal digital marketing, EWM Global suffers from low brand awareness—most potential customers don't know you exist or don't recall your brand when considering plan administration providers. When financial services companies evaluate vendors, they likely default to "known brands" (Computershare) or search online (where you don't appear prominently).

Why This Matters: Brand awareness is the foundation of demand generation. Companies with strong brand awareness (60%+ unaided recall in target market) generate 2-3x more inbound leads and enjoy 20-30% higher close rates because prospects enter sales conversations pre-educated and favorably disposed (Edelman Trust Barometer B2B Brand Research). Weak brand awareness means you're eliminated from consideration before getting a chance to compete.

Business Impact: Low awareness forces EWM Global to rely on expensive direct sales outreach and referral luck rather than efficient inbound marketing. Customer acquisition cost is likely 50-100% higher than it could be with stronger brand. Sales cycles are probably 30-40% longer because you must establish credibility and awareness during the sales process rather than leveraging pre-existing brand recognition.

Remediation Path: Build brand awareness through integrated 18-24 month program: (1) Thought leadership content demonstrating expertise (blog posts, whitepapers, guides on 409A compliance, carry plan design, ERISA considerations); (2) Speaking engagements at industry conferences (NASPP, NCEO, GRC Institute); (3) Strategic PR and media relations in HR technology, fintech, and financial services publications; (4) LinkedIn executive visibility program with consistent CEO/leadership posting; (5) Industry awards and certifications to build third-party credibility; (6) Strategic partnerships with recognized brands (law firms, consultancies) for co-marketing. These activities compound over time to build awareness from current 10-15% to target 40-50% in the financial services plan administration buyer community.

Strategic Marketing Recommendations

EWM Global's marketing transformation requires a comprehensive, sequenced approach addressing foundational gaps (leadership, strategy, measurement) before scaling tactical execution (campaigns, advertising, programs). The following recommendations are prioritized by impact and prerequisite dependencies, with specific timelines, investments, and expected outcomes.

1

Hire Marketing Leader (Director/VP) to Drive Strategic Marketing Transformation

PRIORITY: CRITICAL Timeline: Initiate immediately, hire within 90 days Investment: $140K-$240K annual compensation + $25K recruiting

The Challenge: EWM Global cannot build sophisticated marketing capability without dedicated marketing leadership. Marketing activities are currently fragmented across sales, business development, and reactive administrative support—no one has strategic responsibility, clear accountability, or the expertise to build modern demand generation infrastructure. This leadership vacuum is the root cause of your 50/100 marketing score and inability to scale beyond relationship-driven growth.

The Solution: Recruit and hire an experienced B2B Marketing Director or VP (title depends on seniority) within 90 days. This individual becomes the marketing capability builder, responsible for strategy, team development, demand generation, brand positioning, digital marketing, and customer marketing. The right leader can transform marketing effectiveness by 200-300% within 12-18 months.

Ideal Candidate Profile:

  • Experience: 8-15 years in B2B marketing, preferably fintech, financial services software, or complex B2B professional services
  • Proven Demand Generation: Track record building lead generation programs from scratch in companies with $20-50M revenue
  • Digital Marketing Expertise: Deep knowledge of SEO, content marketing, marketing automation, paid digital, and analytics
  • Strategic Thinking: Can develop positioning, messaging, go-to-market strategy—not just tactical execution
  • Team Builder: Will need to build marketing team over time (hire content marketer, demand generation specialist, marketing ops)
  • Metrics-Driven: Comfortable with analytics, ROI measurement, and proving marketing contribution to revenue
  • Startup/Growth Mentality: Comfortable building infrastructure from scratch, rolling up sleeves, and being hands-on initially

Compensation Benchmarking (Stamford, CT market):

  • Marketing Director: $140K-$180K base + 15-25% bonus = $160K-$225K total comp
  • VP Marketing: $180K-$240K base + 20-30% bonus = $215K-$310K total comp
  • Recommendation: Start with Director-level ($160K-$200K total comp) given you're building from scratch; promote to VP as they prove impact and build team

Roles & Responsibilities (First 18 Months):

  1. Months 1-3 (Assessment & Strategy): Conduct comprehensive marketing audit, competitive analysis, customer research; develop 3-year marketing strategy, positioning, and annual plan; establish baseline metrics and goals; quick-win campaign launches
  2. Months 4-9 (Infrastructure Building): Implement marketing automation and analytics; website redesign and conversion optimization; develop core content assets (case studies, sales materials, thought leadership); launch systematic lead generation programs; hire first marketing team member (content marketer or demand gen specialist)
  3. Months 10-18 (Scale & Optimization): Build integrated demand generation engine (SEO, content, paid digital, ABM); establish customer marketing programs (retention, expansion, advocacy); develop brand awareness campaigns; create marketing/sales alignment and SLAs; prove marketing ROI and secure budget expansion; hire additional marketing team members

Expected Impact:

  • Lead Generation: Increase from estimated 15-30 annual leads to 80-120 leads within 12 months, 150-200 leads by month 18
  • Pipeline Contribution: Marketing-sourced pipeline growing from <10% currently to 30-40% within 18 months
  • Marketing Efficiency: Reduce cost per lead by 25-40% through systematic programs vs. ad-hoc activities
  • Brand Awareness: Increase from estimated 10-15% unaided awareness to 30-40% in target market within 18 months
  • Overall Marketing Score: Improve from 50/100 to 70-75/100 within 18 months through professional leadership

ROI Analysis: Marketing Director at $180K total comp + $100K operating budget = $280K first-year investment. If this generates 25 additional qualified opportunities (vs. current state) at 25% close rate and $300K average client value, result is 6-7 new clients = $1.8-$2.1M new revenue. Even with 18-month ramp, first-year incremental revenue of $600K-$900K provides 2-3x ROI. By year 2-3, ROI increases to 4-6x as programs mature.

Immediate Action: Within 30 days: (1) Write detailed job description and define success metrics for Marketing Director role; (2) Engage executive recruiter specializing in B2B marketing leadership ($25K fee but accelerates search by 60-90 days vs. internal recruiting); (3) Conduct internal planning: reporting structure (likely reports to CEO), budget allocation ($150K-$250K operating budget year 1), and team development roadmap; (4) Parallel-path: Engage fractional CMO or marketing consultant for 90-day interim period while recruiting ($10K-$20K) to conduct initial audit and launch quick-win programs—don't wait for permanent hire to begin transformation.
2

Develop Clear Market Positioning and Differentiated Messaging Strategy

PRIORITY: CRITICAL Timeline: Complete within 90-120 days Investment: $30K-$50K (positioning consultant) + internal team time

The Challenge: EWM Global lacks clear, differentiated positioning that articulates why financial services companies should choose you over Computershare, GPx, or HRSoft. Without crisp positioning, your marketing is generic, sales conversations focus on features/price rather than differentiated value, and prospects default to "safe choice" (largest vendor) or lowest price (commoditization). You cannot build effective marketing campaigns without first clarifying what you stand for and why you're different.

The Solution: Conduct a formal positioning strategy project resulting in: (1) Clear target customer definition; (2) Articulated unique value proposition; (3) Differentiated positioning vs. each major competitor; (4) Core messaging framework; (5) Proof points and supporting evidence; (6) Messaging hierarchy for different buyer personas. This becomes the foundation for all marketing and sales communications.

Recommended Positioning Direction (Hypothesis to Test):

Target Market

Financial services firms (private equity, venture capital, hedge funds, investment banks) with 100-2,000 employees requiring complex deferred compensation and carry/coinvestment plan administration

Core Positioning Statement

"EWM Global is the specialist's choice for complex deferred compensation and carry administration in financial services. While generalist providers treat plan administration as a commodity transaction, we deliver the deep regulatory expertise, financial services domain knowledge, and responsive partnership that sophisticated firms require for their most critical compensation programs."

Key Differentiators vs. Competitors
  • vs. Computershare: "Specialist focus vs. global generalist; partner attention vs. account number; financial services expertise vs. horizontal platform"
  • vs. GPx/HRSoft: "24-year proven track record vs. emerging player; deep 409A/ERISA expertise vs. learning curve; purpose-built for complexity vs. general equity tools"
Three Proof Points
  1. Specialization: 99% revenue focus on deferred comp and carry (vs. competitors' 20-40%); purpose-built platform for complexity
  2. Expertise: 24-year track record, [X] years average employee tenure, [X] collective years of 409A compliance experience
  3. Partnership: Customer Effort Score 4/5, 24-hour response times improving to 4 hours, dedicated account management

Positioning Development Process:

  1. Customer Research (Weeks 1-4): Conduct 15-20 in-depth interviews with current customers, lost deals, and prospects. Key questions: Why did you choose EWM Global? What alternatives did you consider? What problems do we solve vs. competitors? What would you tell a colleague about us? What could we improve? This research uncovers authentic differentiation and validates positioning hypotheses.
  2. Competitive Analysis (Weeks 2-5): Deep analysis of Computershare, GPx, HRSoft positioning, messaging, website content, sales materials, customer reviews. Identify positioning gaps and opportunities where EWM Global can differentiate.
  3. Internal Alignment (Weeks 3-6): Workshop with executive team, sales leadership, and key client-facing staff to define target customer, articulate differentiation, and pressure-test positioning. Ensure internal alignment before external deployment.
  4. Messaging Development (Weeks 6-8): Translate positioning into practical messaging framework: elevator pitch, value propositions, key messages, proof points, buyer persona messaging (CFO vs. HR vs. General Counsel), objection handling, competitive positioning statements.
  5. Message Testing (Weeks 8-10): Test messaging with small sample of prospects and customers through interviews or A/B testing. Refine based on feedback.
  6. Deployment (Weeks 10-12): Roll out positioning across all touchpoints: website, sales presentations, proposals, email templates, LinkedIn profiles, trade show materials, case studies. Conduct sales training on new messaging.

Investment Required:

  • Option 1 - Positioning Consultant: Engage specialist positioning firm (e.g., April Dunford, Ardent Growth, positioning boutiques) for $30K-$50K. Provides external expertise, proven methodology, and accelerated timeline (10-12 weeks vs. 6+ months internal).
  • Option 2 - Marketing Leadership Project: If you hire Marketing Director (Recommendation #1) quickly, this becomes their first major project with $5K-$10K for customer research incentives and tools. Takes 12-16 weeks but builds internal capability.
  • Option 3 - Internal + Advisory: Internal team leads project with positioning advisor providing methodology, frameworks, and coaching at $10K-$15K advisory fee. Middle ground between cost and expertise.

Expected Impact:

  • Win Rate Improvement: Clear positioning typically improves win rates by 15-25% by helping prospects understand differentiation (April Dunford positioning research)
  • Sales Cycle Reduction: Strong messaging reduces sales cycle by 15-20% by pre-qualifying prospects and establishing credibility faster
  • Price Premium: Differentiated positioning enables 10-20% price premium vs. commoditized competitors because you're selling specialized expertise, not generic service
  • Marketing Efficiency: Clear positioning improves marketing conversion by 30-50% because messaging resonates with right audience and filters out poor-fit prospects
  • Employee Alignment: Everyone in organization can clearly articulate what EWM Global does, who you serve, and why you're different—improving consistency across all customer touchpoints
Immediate Action: Within 30 days: (1) Allocate $30K-$50K budget for positioning project; (2) Evaluate positioning consultants or assign to Marketing Director if hired; (3) Begin customer research interviews immediately (can start before formal project)—aim for 15-20 customer interviews within 60 days; (4) Conduct internal positioning workshop with executive team to document current state positioning and alignment gaps; (5) Create positioning project timeline with executive stakeholder accountability—this is CEO-level priority, not delegated marketing task.
3

Implement Marketing Measurement Infrastructure and Analytics

PRIORITY: CRITICAL Timeline: 60-90 days for initial implementation Investment: $40K-$80K (year 1): MarTech platforms, implementation, analytics setup

The Challenge: You cannot optimize what you don't measure. Without systematic marketing analytics, EWM Global is investing $500K-$1M+ annually in marketing activities without knowing what works, what's wasted, or how to improve ROI. This measurement gap prevents data-driven decision making, makes it impossible to prove marketing contribution to revenue, and constrains marketing budget growth because leadership views it as an expense rather than measurable investment.

The Solution: Build comprehensive marketing measurement infrastructure capturing the full customer journey from initial awareness through lead generation, opportunity creation, and closed revenue. Implement marketing technology platforms that enable tracking, develop standardized reporting, and create data-driven marketing culture.

Required Marketing Metrics Framework:

1. Lead Generation Metrics
  • Total Leads Generated: Monthly/quarterly volume by source (web, referral, events, partnerships, paid advertising)
  • Marketing Qualified Leads (MQLs): Leads meeting defined qualification criteria (company size, title, engagement level)
  • Lead Source Performance: Volume, quality, conversion rate, and cost per lead by channel
  • Website Conversion Rate: Visitor-to-lead conversion (target: 3-5% for optimized B2B sites vs. likely current 0.5-1%)
  • Lead Velocity: Rate of lead growth month-over-month (leading indicator of pipeline health)
2. Pipeline & Opportunity Metrics
  • Sales Accepted Leads (SALs): MQLs that sales agrees to follow up (measures lead quality)
  • Marketing-Sourced Pipeline: Dollar value of opportunities generated by marketing activities
  • Marketing-Influenced Pipeline: Opportunities where marketing had any touch (broader measure)
  • Lead-to-Opportunity Conversion Rate: % of leads that become qualified sales opportunities (target: 15-25% for B2B)
  • Time to Convert: Days from lead capture to opportunity creation (faster = better lead quality)
3. Revenue & ROI Metrics
  • Marketing-Sourced Revenue: Closed/won deals where marketing generated initial lead
  • Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC): Total marketing + sales cost divided by new customers acquired
  • CAC by Channel: Acquisition cost broken down by lead source (identifies efficient vs. wasteful channels)
  • Marketing ROI: Revenue generated by marketing divided by marketing investment (target: 3:1 to 5:1 for mature programs)
  • Payback Period: Months to recover CAC (target: <12 months for SaaS/subscription businesses)
4. Brand & Market Metrics
  • Website Traffic: Visitors, page views, time on site, bounce rate (measures market interest)
  • SEO Performance: Keyword rankings, organic search traffic, backlink profile
  • Brand Awareness: Unaided recall in target market (measured via annual survey)
  • Share of Voice: EWM Global mentions vs. competitor mentions in industry conversations/media
  • Content Performance: Downloads, engagement, and conversion rates by content asset
5. Customer Marketing Metrics
  • Net Promoter Score (NPS): Track quarterly, target improvement from 4 to 30+ over 18 months
  • Customer Retention Rate: % of clients renewing (target: 95%+ for plan administration)
  • Expansion Revenue: Upsell, cross-sell, and plan growth from existing customers
  • Customer Referrals: Number and quality of referrals generated by customer advocacy programs
  • Customer Testimonials & Case Studies: Marketing assets generated from customer base

Required Technology Infrastructure:

  1. Marketing Automation Platform ($20K-$50K annually):
    • Recommended: HubSpot Marketing Hub Professional ($18K-$45K annually for 85-employee company) - Comprehensive platform with CRM integration, email marketing, landing pages, forms, lead scoring, reporting, and workflows
    • Alternative: Pardot (Salesforce) ($30K-$60K annually) - If already using Salesforce CRM, native integration advantage
    • Alternative: Marketo ($30K-$80K annually) - Enterprise-grade but potentially over-powered for current needs
    • Functionality Required: Lead capture, email nurturing, lead scoring, campaign tracking, landing page builder, forms, CRM integration, reporting/analytics
  2. CRM Enhancement ($5K-$15K annually): If not already on enterprise CRM, upgrade to Salesforce Professional or equivalent with full marketing integration, campaign tracking, and opportunity source attribution
  3. Website Analytics ($0-$5K annually):
    • Google Analytics 4 (free) - Foundational website tracking
    • Hotjar or similar ($500-$2K annually) - Heatmaps, session recordings, on-site surveys to understand visitor behavior
    • Advanced attribution platform if needed ($3K-$10K annually) - e.g., Bizible, Ruler Analytics for multi-touch attribution
  4. SEO & Content Tools ($5K-$10K annually): Ahrefs, SEMrush, or Moz for keyword research, rank tracking, competitive analysis, backlink monitoring
  5. Call Tracking ($2K-$5K annually): CallRail or similar to attribute phone inquiries to marketing sources
  6. Reporting & Visualization ($0-$5K annually): Databox, Klipfolio, or Tableau for marketing dashboards; potentially included in marketing automation platform

Implementation Roadmap:

  • Days 1-30: Select and purchase marketing automation platform; implement basic lead tracking and form submissions; set up integration with existing CRM; deploy website analytics with goal tracking
  • Days 30-60: Define lead lifecycle stages (Lead → MQL → SAL → Opportunity → Customer); implement lead scoring model; create initial email nurture workflows; establish campaign tracking protocols
  • Days 60-90: Build marketing dashboard with key metrics; train sales team on lead tracking and source attribution; conduct first closed-loop analysis (which lead sources generated closed/won deals); launch first measurement-driven campaign optimizations
  • Days 90-180: Refine measurement methodology based on learnings; implement advanced attribution models; develop comprehensive monthly/quarterly marketing business review process; prove marketing ROI to executive team

Expected Impact:

  • Marketing Efficiency: 15-25% improvement in marketing ROI within 6-12 months by eliminating low-performing activities and optimizing high-performers (Forrester Marketing Measurement Research)
  • Lead Quality: 20-30% increase in lead-to-opportunity conversion through better targeting and lead scoring
  • Budget Justification: Ability to prove marketing contribution enables 30-50% budget growth by demonstrating measurable ROI
  • Sales Productivity: 10-15% improvement as sales team focuses on higher-quality, better-qualified leads vs. chasing low-probability opportunities
  • Strategic Clarity: Data-driven insights guide strategic decisions: which markets to target, which messages resonate, which channels to scale
Immediate Action: Within 30 days: (1) Allocate $40K-$80K budget for marketing technology and implementation; (2) Evaluate and select marketing automation platform (recommend HubSpot for ease of use and comprehensive capability); (3) Audit current CRM utilization and identify integration requirements; (4) Define lead lifecycle stages and qualification criteria through sales-marketing alignment workshop; (5) Assign project manager (likely future Marketing Director or interim consultant) to drive implementation with 90-day deadline. This is foundational infrastructure—don't launch new marketing programs without measurement capability in place.
4

Build Integrated Demand Generation Engine (SEO, Content, Digital Marketing)

PRIORITY: HIGH Timeline: 6-month initial build, 12-18 months to maturity Investment: $200K-$400K annually (includes staff, programs, tools, content)

The Challenge: Referral-dependent lead generation produces 15-30 leads annually—insufficient to support 20% growth requiring 100-150 qualified opportunities. EWM Global needs systematic, scalable demand generation programs that consistently produce qualified leads independent of referral luck. This requires building capabilities in SEO, content marketing, paid digital advertising, account-based marketing, and marketing automation.

The Solution: Develop integrated demand generation engine combining multiple channels working together: inbound marketing (SEO + content) attracting prospects searching for solutions, outbound account-based marketing targeting specific high-value firms, strategic partnerships generating warm referrals, and event marketing building relationships. Each channel contributes 20-40 leads annually; combined they produce 100-150+ qualified leads.

Demand Generation Architecture:

Channel 1: SEO & Inbound Marketing (Target: 30-50 leads annually)

Strategy: Rank on first page of Google for high-intent search terms that financial services HR/CFO leaders use when researching plan administration: "deferred compensation plan administrator," "Section 409A compliance services," "carry plan administration," "coinvestment plan administrator," "hedge fund deferred comp plans," etc. Create comprehensive educational content that demonstrates expertise and captures leads.

Specific Tactics:

  • Keyword Research & Strategy: Identify 20-30 high-value keywords with commercial intent and achievable competition levels; prioritize long-tail keywords where EWM Global can rank faster than broad terms
  • Website Optimization: Redesign website with SEO-optimized structure, fast loading, mobile responsive, clear conversion paths, compelling CTAs
  • Content Creation: Publish 2-4 blog posts monthly on topics prospects search: "409A Compliance Checklist for PE Firms," "Carry Plan Design Best Practices," "Deferred Comp vs. Equity: What's Right for Your Firm," etc. (48-96 posts annually)
  • Premium Content Offers: Develop 4-6 downloadable resources (ebooks, guides, whitepapers) that require form submission: "Complete Guide to Section 409A Compliance," "Carry Plan Administration Buyer's Guide," "Deferred Compensation Trends in Private Equity" (lead generation assets)
  • Technical SEO: Implement proper site structure, schema markup, page speed optimization, mobile optimization, HTTPS security, XML sitemaps
  • Link Building: Earn backlinks from industry sites, partner organizations, guest posting, digital PR to build domain authority

Investment: $80K-$150K annually (Content marketer hire $70K-$90K + SEO tools $8K-$12K + agency support $20K-$50K for technical SEO/link building)

Timeline: 6-12 months to first page rankings; 12-18 months to consistent lead generation; SEO is long-term investment with compounding returns

Expected Results: 30-50 qualified leads annually by month 12-18, growing to 80-120 leads by year 3 as content library and domain authority build

Channel 2: Account-Based Marketing / Targeted Outbound (Target: 25-40 leads annually)

Strategy: Identify 50-100 specific target accounts (PE firms, hedge funds, investment banks) that match ideal customer profile and run personalized campaigns combining multiple touches: LinkedIn advertising, direct mail, personalized email sequences, phone outreach, executive engagement. Focus marketing resources on companies you most want to win rather than broad campaigns.

Specific Tactics:

  • Target Account Selection: Build list of 50-100 named accounts based on criteria: financial services firm, 100-2,000 employees, likely has deferred comp or carry plans, annual revenue $50M+, geographic fit
  • Account Research: Deep research on each target: decision makers, current provider (if known), pain points, recent news/funding/growth, connection points
  • Personalized Content: Create account-specific content: custom one-pagers, industry-specific case studies, personalized video messages from executives
  • Multi-Channel Campaigns: 6-8 touch sequences over 3-4 months: (1) LinkedIn InMail from executive; (2) Educational content send; (3) Direct mail gift/dimensional mail; (4) Personalized email from AE; (5) Phone call; (6) Event invitation; (7-8) Follow-up touches
  • LinkedIn Advertising: Hyper-targeted ads to decision makers at target accounts showcasing expertise and case studies
  • Sales & Marketing Coordination: Tight alignment between ABM marketing campaigns and sales outreach—marketing warms accounts, sales closes

Investment: $60K-$100K annually (ABM platform $15K-$30K + LinkedIn ads $25K-$40K + direct mail $8K-$15K + content creation $12K-$15K)

Timeline: 3-6 months to first results; ABM generates higher-quality leads with faster ramp than inbound SEO

Expected Results: 25-40 qualified opportunities annually from target accounts with 35-45% higher close rates than cold leads (ABM focuses on best-fit accounts)

Channel 3: Strategic Partnerships & Referral Programs (Target: 20-35 leads annually)

Strategy: Formalize and scale the relationship-driven referral model that has worked historically. Identify complementary service providers (benefits law firms, compensation consultants, HR advisory firms, financial advisors) that serve the same target market and build formal referral partnerships with co-marketing, revenue sharing, or reciprocal referrals.

Specific Tactics:

  • Partner Identification: Map ecosystem of service providers touching financial services compensation: ERISA law firms, benefits consultants (Mercer, Aon, WTW), compensation advisory boutiques, PE/VC advisory firms, accounting firms serving PE/VC
  • Partnership Development: Recruit 8-12 strategic partners with formal agreements: joint marketing activities, referral fees/revenue sharing, co-branded content, joint client events
  • Partner Enablement: Equip partners with materials to recommend EWM Global: one-pagers, case studies, presentation decks, referral commission structure, joint proposal templates
  • Co-Marketing Programs: Joint webinars, co-authored whitepapers, shared conference booths, client roundtables—activities that benefit both partners and generate leads
  • Customer Referral Program: Formalize customer referral incentives: referral bonuses, service credits, recognition programs for clients who introduce EWM Global to peer companies

Investment: $35K-$60K annually (Partner manager/coordinator role part-time $25K-$35K + partner materials $5K-$10K + co-marketing budget $5K-$15K)

Timeline: 3-4 months to recruit partners; 6-9 months to generate consistent referrals as relationships deepen

Expected Results: 20-35 qualified leads annually from 8-12 active partnerships, with higher close rates (40-50%) than cold leads due to trusted referral source

Channel 4: Industry Events & Thought Leadership (Target: 15-25 leads annually)

Strategy: Establish EWM Global as thought leader in deferred compensation and carry administration through strategic event participation: speaking engagements, conference sponsorships, proprietary research, and hosted executive roundtables. Events generate leads while building brand awareness and credibility.

Specific Tactics:

  • Conference Speaking: Secure speaking slots at industry conferences (NASPP, NCEO, GRC Institute events, PE/VC industry conferences) presenting on 409A compliance, carry plan trends, plan design best practices
  • Strategic Sponsorships: Select 2-3 conferences annually for booth presence and sponsorship visibility (avoid over-spending on low-ROI events)
  • Proprietary Research: Conduct annual industry research study (survey 200-300 financial services firms on compensation trends, publish findings report, generate media coverage and speaking opportunities)
  • Executive Roundtables: Host intimate 15-20 person dinners or breakfast briefings in major markets (NYC, Boston, SF) for CFOs/HR leaders at target accounts—educational content + networking
  • Webinar Series: Monthly educational webinars on technical topics (409A updates, plan design, compliance trends)—generate 15-25 registrations per webinar, convert 10-20% to qualified leads

Investment: $45K-$80K annually (Conference sponsorships $20K-$35K + events/dinners $15K-$25K + research study $10K-$20K)

Timeline: Immediate impact from sponsorships/attendance; 6-12 months to establish speaking presence and thought leadership reputation

Expected Results: 15-25 qualified leads annually + significant brand awareness lift + sales enablement (credibility from speaking/thought leadership improves close rates)

Integrated Demand Generation Summary:

Channel Annual Investment Expected Leads (Year 1-2) Lead Quality / Close Rate Primary Benefit
SEO & Inbound Marketing $80K-$150K 30-50 leads Medium (20-25% close rate) Scalable, compounding, low CPL long-term
Account-Based Marketing $60K-$100K 25-40 leads High (35-45% close rate) Targets best-fit accounts, shorter sales cycle
Strategic Partnerships $35K-$60K 20-35 leads Very High (40-50% close rate) Trusted referrals, warm introductions
Events & Thought Leadership $45K-$80K 15-25 leads High (30-40% close rate) Brand awareness, credibility, relationship building
TOTAL $220K-$390K 90-150 leads Avg: 30-35% close rate 27-52 new clients annually

Expected Impact: This integrated demand generation engine produces 90-150 qualified leads annually (vs. current 15-30), resulting in 27-52 new client wins at 30-35% average close rate. At $200K-$400K average client value, this represents $5.4M-$20.8M in new annual recurring revenue—well exceeding your $4.8M growth target. The integrated approach is critical: multiple channels working together create consistent pipeline vs. relying on any single channel.

Immediate Action: This is a 6-12 month build requiring the Marketing Director (Recommendation #1) to orchestrate. Near-term (next 90 days): (1) Hire content marketer to begin SEO/content program; (2) Engage SEO agency for technical audit and keyword strategy ($10K-$15K project); (3) Select ABM platform and build target account list (can start with existing sales target list); (4) Identify 5-8 potential strategic partners and begin outreach; (5) Register for 2-3 conferences in next 6 months and submit speaking proposals. Don't try to launch all channels simultaneously—phase in over 6-9 months as capabilities build.
5

Launch Customer Marketing Program to Improve NPS, Retention, and Expansion Revenue

PRIORITY: HIGH Timeline: 90-day design, 6-month implementation, ongoing optimization Investment: $80K-$150K annually (program costs + 0.5-1.0 FTE customer marketing)

The Challenge: NPS of 4 indicates weak customer advocacy and limited referral generation from your existing base. With 50-80 clients representing $24M revenue, there's significant untapped expansion opportunity through cross-sell, upsell, and growth with existing clients. Customer marketing (focusing on retention, expansion, and advocacy) is the fastest path to incremental revenue with lowest customer acquisition cost—yet it's currently neglected.

The Solution: Build systematic customer marketing program with three objectives: (1) Improve customer satisfaction and loyalty (increase NPS from 4 to 30+ over 18 months); (2) Drive expansion revenue (cross-sell, upsell, plan growth) targeting 10-15% of new revenue from existing clients; (3) Generate referrals and testimonials (turning satisfied customers into active advocates). Customer marketing delivers 40-50% of growth target at 1/5th the CAC of new customer acquisition.

Customer Marketing Program Components:

1. Systematic Customer Feedback & Voice of Customer Program

Current Gap: No formal feedback collection means you don't understand customer satisfaction drivers, pain points, or reasons behind NPS of 4

Program Design:

  • Quarterly NPS Surveys: Email survey to all clients measuring NPS + qualitative feedback on satisfaction, service quality, areas for improvement. Track NPS by client segment, tenure, and service line.
  • Annual Relationship Reviews: In-depth interviews with top 20-30 clients (80% of revenue) covering satisfaction, strategic needs, expansion opportunities, competitive threats, improvement suggestions
  • Transactional Feedback: Post-implementation surveys, support ticket satisfaction ratings, and project completion feedback to catch issues early
  • Customer Advisory Board: Invite 8-12 influential clients to quarterly advisory meetings providing input on product roadmap, service enhancements, and industry trends—deepens relationships and provides strategic intelligence
  • Feedback Analysis & Action: Monthly review of all customer feedback with cross-functional team (product, operations, customer success), prioritize improvements, communicate actions taken back to customers (closes loop)

Investment: $15K-$25K annually (Survey platform $3K-$5K + incentives/gifts $5K-$10K + customer advisory board events $7K-$10K)

Expected Impact: Understanding satisfaction drivers enables targeted improvements; closing the feedback loop demonstrates you listen (increases NPS 8-12 points); customer advisory board strengthens relationships with top accounts (reduces churn risk 40-60%)

2. Customer Success & Proactive Account Management

Current Gap: Likely reactive account management—responding to client requests rather than proactively driving value and identifying expansion

Program Design:

  • Customer Segmentation: Segment clients by strategic value (revenue, growth potential, reference-ability, strategic fit) and tailor engagement model: Strategic accounts get executive-level quarterly business reviews; core accounts get semi-annual reviews; smaller accounts get annual check-ins
  • Health Score Monitoring: Develop customer health scoring model tracking engagement (system usage, support tickets, payment timeliness, communication responsiveness) and identifying at-risk accounts 3-6 months before potential churn
  • Quarterly Business Reviews (QBRs): For top 20-30 accounts, conduct formal QBRs presenting: value delivered (metrics on plan administration, compliance support, cost savings), service performance vs. SLAs, upcoming regulatory changes/industry trends, expansion opportunities (cross-sell other services, add plans, increase participants)
  • Success Planning: Collaborate with clients on annual success plans defining mutual objectives, key initiatives, and success metrics—aligns EWM Global as strategic partner rather than vendor
  • Proactive Communication: Regular touchpoints beyond issue resolution: monthly newsletters with compliance updates, quarterly webinars on industry trends, annual benchmarking reports comparing client's programs to peer data

Investment: $40K-$70K annually (0.5-1.0 FTE customer success manager $60K-$90K if dedicated role, or formalize existing account management with structured processes; customer communication platform $5K-$10K; benchmarking/analytics tools $5K-$15K)

Expected Impact: Proactive account management increases retention from estimated 90% to 95-97% (reduces churn by 40-70%); QBRs identify expansion opportunities generating $1.5M-$3M in expansion revenue annually (10-12% of base); early identification of at-risk accounts enables intervention before loss

3. Customer Advocacy & Referral Generation Program

Current Gap: Low NPS of 4 indicates minimal organic advocacy; no systematic program to activate satisfied customers for referrals, testimonials, case studies, or reviews

Program Design:

  • Promoter Identification: From quarterly NPS surveys, identify Promoters (score 9-10) who are willing advocates—typically 20-35% of customer base
  • Referral Program: Formal program incentivizing customer referrals with rewards: (a) Service credits ($2K-$5K off annual fees); (b) Charitable donations to customer's chosen nonprofit ($2K-$5K); (c) Gift cards or experiences ($500-$1K); (d) Exclusive benefits (priority support, early access to new features). Make referral process easy with simple form, clear communication of rewards, and fast follow-up.
  • Case Study Development: Work with 6-10 satisfied customers annually to develop detailed case studies: customer challenge, EWM Global solution, quantified business outcomes. Use across website, sales presentations, proposals, and content marketing.
  • Testimonial & Review Collection: Systematic outreach requesting testimonials (website/sales materials), LinkedIn recommendations, and reviews on G2/Capterra/industry sites. Target: 15-20 new testimonials annually.
  • Customer Reference Program: Recruit 15-20 referenceable customers willing to speak with prospects. Provide incentives (service credits, recognition, exclusive briefings) and make reference calls easy (brief them on prospect, provide talking points, limit frequency)
  • Customer Awards & Recognition: Annual "Customer Innovation Award" recognizing creative plan designs or best practices—generates goodwill, case study content, and PR opportunities

Investment: $25K-$55K annually (Referral rewards/incentives $15K-$30K for 10-20 referrals; case study development $8K-$20K at $1.5-$3K per case study; awards/recognition $2K-$5K)

Expected Impact: Customer referral program generates 15-25 qualified leads annually with 45-55% close rates (trusted referrals)—represents 7-14 new clients worth $1.4M-$5.6M annually; case studies improve win rates by 15-25%; testimonials and reviews improve website conversion by 20-30%; referenceable customers accelerate sales cycles by 15-25% (reduces time-to-close)

Customer Marketing ROI Analysis:

Customer Marketing Initiative Annual Investment Expected Revenue Impact ROI
Improved Retention (90% → 95%) $40K-$70K (customer success program) $1.2M retained revenue 17:1 to 30:1
Expansion Revenue (cross-sell/upsell) $40K-$70K (proactive account mgmt) $1.5M-$3M expansion revenue 21:1 to 75:1
Customer Referrals $25K-$55K (advocacy program) $1.4M-$5.6M from 7-14 referred clients 25:1 to 224:1
TOTAL CUSTOMER MARKETING $80K-$150K $4.1M-$9.8M total impact 27:1 to 123:1 ROI

Strategic Insight: Customer marketing delivers 85-205% of your $4.8M growth target at investment of $80K-$150K vs. new customer acquisition requiring $200K-$400K for similar results. This is the highest-ROI marketing investment EWM Global can make. Combined with new customer demand generation (Recommendation #4), balanced portfolio of 60% new customer acquisition + 40% customer marketing creates efficient, sustainable growth engine.

Immediate Action: Within 60 days: (1) Implement quarterly NPS survey—can start immediately with simple email survey using SurveyMonkey or Qualtrics (cost: <$1K); (2) Segment customer base by strategic value and assign account responsibility with clear engagement expectations; (3) Schedule QBRs with top 10 accounts in next 90 days; (4) Launch pilot referral program with top 15-20 customers and test incentive structures; (5) Identify 3-5 customers for initial case study development. Customer marketing can generate near-term wins (referrals, expansion) while longer-term demand generation programs build—this is your fastest path to incremental revenue.

Marketing Transformation Roadmap

Transforming EWM Global's marketing from 50/100 to 75-80/100 over 18-24 months requires sequenced implementation—building foundational capabilities before scaling tactical programs. The roadmap below prioritizes quick wins while establishing infrastructure for sustainable long-term growth.

Phase 1: Foundation Building (Months 1-6)

Establish marketing leadership, strategy, and measurement infrastructure

Key Objectives
  • Hire Marketing Director/VP and establish marketing function
  • Complete positioning and messaging strategy
  • Implement marketing measurement and analytics infrastructure
  • Launch initial customer marketing programs (NPS, feedback, referrals)
  • Build marketing technology foundation (automation, CRM integration, analytics)
Major Deliverables
  • Marketing Director hired and onboarded (Month 1-3)
  • 3-year marketing strategy and annual plan completed (Month 2-4)
  • Market positioning and messaging framework finalized (Month 2-4)
  • Marketing automation platform implemented with lead tracking (Month 3-5)
  • Marketing dashboard with key metrics operational (Month 4-6)
  • Quarterly NPS survey launched and baseline established (Month 2)
  • Customer referral program pilot with top 20 accounts (Month 4-6)
  • First 3-5 customer case studies completed (Month 5-6)
Investment: Phase 1

$280K-$420K over 6 months

  • Marketing Director compensation (6 months): $80K-$120K
  • Positioning consultant: $30K-$50K
  • Marketing technology (automation, tools): $30K-$60K
  • Customer marketing programs: $15K-$30K
  • Content development (case studies, sales materials): $15K-$25K
  • Recruiting, consulting, miscellaneous: $25K-$40K
Expected Outcomes
  • Marketing leadership and accountability in place
  • Clear positioning and messaging driving sales effectiveness
  • Measurement capability enabling data-driven optimization
  • NPS baseline established with improvement roadmap
  • Initial customer referrals and expansion opportunities identified
  • Marketing infrastructure ready to scale tactical programs in Phase 2

Phase 2: Demand Generation Launch (Months 7-12)

Build and launch integrated demand generation engine

Key Objectives
  • Launch SEO and content marketing program
  • Implement account-based marketing for target accounts
  • Establish strategic partnerships and referral channels
  • Execute event marketing and thought leadership initiatives
  • Scale customer marketing programs across full client base
Major Deliverables
  • Website redesign with SEO optimization launched (Month 7-9)
  • Content marketing engine producing 2-4 posts monthly (Month 7 ongoing)
  • First 2-3 premium content offers (ebooks/guides) published (Month 8-10)
  • ABM program targeting 50-75 named accounts operational (Month 8-10)
  • 8-10 strategic partnerships recruited and activated (Month 7-12)
  • Speaking engagements secured at 2-3 industry conferences (Month 9-12)
  • Quarterly business reviews implemented with top 30 accounts (Month 7-9)
  • First marketing hire beyond Director: Content Marketer (Month 8-10)
Investment: Phase 2

$420K-$680K over 6 months

  • Marketing Director compensation (6 months): $90K-$130K
  • Content Marketer hire (4-5 months): $25K-$40K
  • Website redesign: $30K-$60K
  • SEO/content program (agency support, tools): $45K-$80K
  • ABM platform and campaigns: $35K-$60K
  • Events, partnerships, thought leadership: $40K-$70K
  • Customer marketing scale-up: $35K-$60K
  • Marketing technology, content, misc: $40K-$70K
Expected Outcomes
  • Lead generation growing to 40-70 qualified leads (vs. 15-30 baseline)
  • Website traffic increasing 50-100% from SEO optimization
  • ABM generating 10-15 qualified opportunities from target accounts
  • Partnership channels contributing 8-12 warm referrals
  • Brand awareness measurably improving through content and events
  • Customer expansion revenue of $500K-$1.5M identified
  • NPS improving from 4 to 15-20 through customer marketing programs

Phase 3: Optimization & Scale (Months 13-24)

Optimize programs, scale what works, achieve sustainable growth engine

Key Objectives
  • Optimize demand generation based on data and early results
  • Scale successful channels and eliminate underperformers
  • Build brand awareness through sustained content and PR
  • Expand marketing team to support scaled operations
  • Achieve target marketing maturity score of 75-80/100
Major Deliverables
  • SEO driving consistent first-page rankings for 10-15 target keywords (Month 15-18)
  • Content library of 80-120 blog posts establishing thought leadership (Month 24)
  • ABM program expanded to 100+ target accounts (Month 14-16)
  • 10-15 active strategic partnerships generating steady referrals (Month 18)
  • Proprietary industry research study published with PR/media coverage (Month 16-18)
