Research Currency & Application Note

Temporal Relevance: All referenced research represents the most current available data as of 2024-2025. Where multi-year studies are cited, the most recent iterations have been prioritized.

Peer Group Selection: Benchmarks were selected from peer groups most relevant to EWM Global's profile: B2B fintech/financial services technology companies with $20-50M revenue, professional services firms, and SaaS companies serving enterprise clients.

Conservative Bias: Where research presented ranges or conflicting data points, conservative (lower) estimates were generally applied to impact calculations to ensure recommendations are achievable and projections are credible.

Contextual Adaptation: Generic industry benchmarks were adjusted for EWM Global's specific context (24-year maturity, specialized niche, 10% market share, fintech regulatory environment) to ensure relevance and applicability.

5. Glossary of Terms

Key business terminology, metrics, and acronyms used throughout the assessment report.

A-C

ABM (Account-Based Marketing)
Strategic marketing approach targeting high-value accounts with personalized campaigns rather than broad-based marketing. Research shows ABM delivers 171% higher average contract values (ITSMA).
ACV (Annual Contract Value)
The normalized annual revenue value of a customer contract, excluding one-time fees. Used to compare deal sizes across different contract lengths.
API (Application Programming Interface)
Software interface that allows different applications to communicate and exchange data. Critical for integration and scalability in fintech platforms.
Automation Maturity
The degree to which manual, repetitive processes have been replaced with automated workflows and technology. Scored 1-5, with 4+ representing fintech best practices.
B2B (Business-to-Business)
Commercial transactions and relationships between businesses rather than with individual consumers. EWM Global operates in the B2B model serving financial services companies.
BCP (Business Continuity Plan)
Documented procedures for maintaining or rapidly resuming business operations after disruption. Measured by RTO (Recovery Time Objective).
Benchmarking
Comparing company performance metrics against industry standards, peer group averages, or best-in-class performers to identify gaps and improvement opportunities.
Bottom Quartile
The lowest-performing 25% of peer companies on a given metric. Indicates significant underperformance requiring priority attention.
CAC (Customer Acquisition Cost)
Total sales and marketing costs divided by number of new customers acquired in a period. EWM Global's CAC: $54,000. B2B fintech median: $40-60K.
Carry/Co-investment Administration
Management of carried interest and co-investment plans for private equity, venture capital, and investment professionals. 30% of EWM Global's revenue.
Cash Runway
Number of months a company can operate before depleting cash reserves, calculated as current cash divided by monthly burn rate. Minimum recommendation for growth companies: 9-12 months.
CES (Customer Effort Score)
Metric measuring how easy it is for customers to interact with a company. Scored 1-5; EWM Global: 4/5. High-effort experiences increase churn by 96% (Gartner).
Churn Rate
Percentage of customers who discontinue service in a period. Inverse of retention rate. EWM Global's retention: 98%, implying 2% churn—excellent for B2B.
CI/CD (Continuous Integration/Continuous Deployment)
DevOps practice of automatically testing and deploying code changes. Accelerates feature releases by 60-80% while reducing errors.
Cloud-Native Architecture
Application design using cloud computing services (AWS, Azure, GCP) with containers, microservices, and automated scaling. Enables 5-10x growth capacity.
Compliance Maturity
Sophistication of compliance program on 5-level scale: Level 1 (Ad-Hoc) to Level 5 (Optimized). EWM Global: Level 3-4 (Defined to Managed).
COSO ERM
Committee of Sponsoring Organizations Enterprise Risk Management Framework. Industry-standard approach for identifying, assessing, and managing business risks.

D-G

Data Maturity
Sophistication of data management, governance, and analytics capabilities on 5-level scale. EWM Global: Level 4-5 (Optimized/Data-Driven)—top 15% of companies.
Deferred Compensation Plan Administration
Management of non-qualified deferred compensation (NQDC) plans allowing executives to defer salary/bonus. Subject to IRS Section 409A. 69% of EWM Global's revenue.
Digital Maturity
Overall technology sophistication across systems, processes, and culture. 5-level model from "Digital Skeptic" to "Digital Leader." EWM Global: Level 4 (Digital+).
DMAIC
Six Sigma improvement methodology: Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve, Control. Used for data-driven process optimization and waste elimination.
DSO (Days Sales Outstanding)
Average days to collect payment from customers. Lower DSO improves cash flow. Best practice: 30-45 days. EWM Global's DSO: Unknown, needs measurement.
EDR (Endpoint Detection and Response)
Cybersecurity technology for detecting and responding to threats on endpoints (computers, mobile devices). Critical for fintech companies handling sensitive financial data.
ERM (Enterprise Risk Management)
Holistic approach to identifying and managing strategic, operational, financial, and compliance risks. EWM Global: Level 4 maturity—top 35% of companies.
ERISA (Employee Retirement Income Security Act)
Federal law governing employee benefit plans including deferred compensation. Creates fiduciary obligations and DOL compliance requirements for plan administrators.
Fintech
Financial technology companies providing software/technology-enabled services to financial services industry. EWM Global serves fintech/financial services sector.
Flywheel Model
HubSpot's customer-centric business model where exceptional customer experience drives word-of-mouth growth, reducing CAC and accelerating revenue (vs. traditional funnel).
FTE (Full-Time Equivalent)
Measurement of employee capacity normalizing part-time to full-time hours. Used for productivity calculations and resource planning. EWM Global: 85 FTEs.
Gemba Walk
Lean management practice where leaders observe actual work processes to identify improvement opportunities. "Gemba" = Japanese for "the real place."
Governance
Systems for organizational decision-making, oversight, and accountability. Includes board of directors, advisory boards, and management oversight structures.
GRC (Governance, Risk, Compliance)
Integrated approach to managing corporate governance, enterprise risk management, and regulatory compliance. OCEG provides GRC capability model and benchmarks.
Gross Margin
Revenue minus direct costs (COGS), expressed as percentage of revenue. Indicates pricing power and operational efficiency. EWM Global: 32% vs. 60-80% fintech benchmark.

H-N

HRIS (Human Resources Information System)
Software for managing HR processes including payroll, benefits, time tracking, and employee data. Examples: BambooHR, Workday, ADP.
IRS Section 409A
Tax code governing deferred compensation plan design and operation. Violations result in immediate taxation plus 20% penalty to participants. Critical for EWM Global's core business.
IT Infrastructure Health Index
Composite score of technology systems reliability, network performance, and IT support quality. EWM Global: 4.67/5 (99.9%+ uptime)—world-class.
ITSM (IT Service Management)
Structured approach to delivering IT services using frameworks like ITIL. Includes helpdesk systems, SLA management, and continuous service improvement.
Kaizen
Japanese philosophy of continuous improvement through small, incremental changes. Core component of Lean methodology and Toyota Production System.
Key Person Risk
Business vulnerability from concentration of critical knowledge, relationships, or decisions with specific individuals. Mitigated through succession planning and documentation.
Lean Principles
Methodology for maximizing customer value while minimizing waste. Originated from Toyota Production System, adapted for services by Lean Enterprise Institute.
LMS (Learning Management System)
Software platform for delivering and tracking employee training. Examples: Lessonly, Trainual, LinkedIn Learning. Critical for compliance training documentation.
LTV (Customer Lifetime Value)
Total net revenue expected from customer over entire relationship. EWM Global: $1M average. Used with CAC to calculate LTV:CAC ratio.
LTV:CAC Ratio
Customer lifetime value divided by acquisition cost. Healthy benchmark: 3:1+. EWM Global: 18.5:1 (world-class, top 10%)—each $1 spent acquiring customers returns $18.50.
Margin
Profitability metric expressed as percentage. Gross margin = (Revenue - COGS) / Revenue. Net margin = Net profit / Revenue. Operating margin = Operating profit / Revenue.
MEDDIC
B2B sales qualification framework: Metrics, Economic Buyer, Decision Criteria, Decision Process, Identify Pain, Champion. Improves win rates by 25% (Sales Benchmark Index).
MFA (Multi-Factor Authentication)
Security control requiring multiple verification methods (password + phone code, biometric). Prevents 99.9% of automated attacks (Microsoft Security).
NIST Cybersecurity Framework
National Institute of Standards and Technology framework for managing cybersecurity risk: Identify, Protect, Detect, Respond, Recover. Industry standard for fintech.
NPS (Net Promoter Score)
Customer loyalty metric from -100 to +100 based on "How likely to recommend?" Promoters (9-10) minus Detractors (0-6). EWM Global: 4. B2B fintech median: 30-40.
NRR (Net Revenue Retention)
Percentage of revenue retained from existing customers including expansion and churn. >100% indicates expansion exceeds churn. World-class B2B SaaS: 110-130%.

O-R

OKR (Objectives and Key Results)
Goal-setting framework popularized by Google. Each Objective has 3-5 measurable Key Results. Typically set quarterly with monthly reviews for agile strategy execution.
Operational Efficiency
Ratio of outputs to inputs; how effectively resources convert to results. Scored 1-5. EWM Global: 3.0/5 (60%)—suggests 20-30% capacity loss to waste and rework.
P&L (Profit and Loss Statement)
Financial report showing revenue, expenses, and profit over a period. Also called Income Statement. Critical for understanding business unit and product line profitability.
Percentile Rank
Position within peer group distribution. 75th percentile = better than 75% of peers. Used to contextualize company performance against industry benchmarks.
Pre-Mortem Analysis
Strategic planning technique where teams imagine a future failure and work backwards to identify causes. Increases problem identification by 30-40% vs. standard planning (HBR).
QBR (Quarterly Business Review)
Strategic meeting with key customers or internal teams to review performance, discuss challenges, and plan next quarter. Critical component of strategic account management.
RACI Matrix
Decision-making framework defining who is Responsible (does work), Accountable (owns outcome), Consulted (provides input), and Informed (notified). Accelerates organizational velocity by 35-50%.
Retention Rate
Percentage of customers retained over a period. EWM Global: 98% repeat sales rate (world-class, top 5%). Inverse is churn rate (2% for EWM Global).
ROI (Return on Investment)
Profitability metric: (Benefits - Costs) / Costs × 100%. Used to evaluate initiative effectiveness. Positive ROI = benefits exceed costs.
RPA (Robotic Process Automation)
Software "robots" automating repetitive, rule-based tasks (data entry, report generation, reconciliation). Delivers 15-25% efficiency gains in back-office functions.
RTO (Recovery Time Objective)
Target timeframe for restoring business operations after disruption. EWM Global: 24-72 hours (good). Best practice for fintech mission-critical systems: <24 hours.
Rule of 40
SaaS Capital framework: Growth Rate + Profit Margin should ≥ 40% for healthy companies. EWM Global: 20% target growth + 32% margin = 52% (exceeds if margin accurate).

S-Z

SaaS (Software as a Service)
Cloud-based software delivery model with subscription pricing. Customers access applications via internet rather than installing software. Scalable revenue model for fintech.
Sales Cycle
Average time from first customer contact to closed deal. EWM Global: 270 days (2.5x industry benchmark). Long cycles constrain sales capacity and growth velocity.
Scalability
Ability to handle increased workload/growth without proportional cost increases. EWM Global IT scalability: 4/5 (supports 2-3x growth). Target: 5/5 (5-10x capacity).
SIEM (Security Information and Event Management)
Cybersecurity platform aggregating and analyzing security alerts from across IT environment. Enables rapid threat detection and response. Critical for SOC 2 compliance.
Six Sigma
Data-driven quality management methodology targeting 99.997% defect-free processes. Uses DMAIC framework. Often combined with Lean for "Lean Six Sigma."
SLA (Service Level Agreement)
Documented commitment to service quality standards (response time, uptime, resolution time). Example: EWM Global target <4 hour response time for B2B standard vs. current 24 hours.
SOC 2 Type II
AICPA security audit verifying controls over 6-12 months. Type I = design, Type II = operating effectiveness. Increasingly required by enterprise financial services clients.
Strategic Account Management
Systematic approach to growing revenue from key customers through relationship development, whitespace analysis, QBRs, and expansion plays. Delivers 15-25% account growth.
SWOT Analysis
Strategic planning framework examining Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, and Threats. Used throughout EWM Global assessment to identify priorities.
Top Quartile
Top 25% of peer companies on a metric. Indicates strong competitive performance. Goal for most business dimensions.
Turnover Rate
Percentage of employees who leave (voluntary and involuntary) annually. EWM Global: 19.9% vs. fintech benchmark 13-16%. High turnover costs $1.2-1.7M annually in replacement.
Unit Economics
Profitability of individual customer/transaction. Key metrics: CAC, LTV, LTV:CAC ratio, gross margin, payback period. Foundation of scalable business models.
Value Proposition Canvas
Strategyzer tool for articulating how products/services address customer pain points and create gains. Used to clarify competitive differentiation.
Value Stream Mapping
Lean technique visually mapping all steps in a process to identify waste, delays, and improvement opportunities. Foundation of Lean Service operations.
Win Rate
Percentage of sales opportunities that convert to closed deals. EWM Global: 10% vs. B2B median 20-30%. Doubling win rate could add $480K+ in new customer revenue.
Working Capital
Current assets minus current liabilities. Measures short-term financial health and liquidity. EWM Global: $1.5M (6.25% of revenue) vs. healthy benchmark 15-20%.
World-Class
Top 10-15% performance; represents best-in-class standards and sustainable competitive advantage. Goal standard for critical business dimensions.

Acronym Quick Reference

  • ABM - Account-Based Marketing
  • ACV - Annual Contract Value
  • API - Application Programming Interface
  • B2B - Business-to-Business
  • BCP - Business Continuity Plan
  • CAC - Customer Acquisition Cost
  • CES - Customer Effort Score
  • CI/CD - Continuous Integration/Continuous Deployment
  • COGS - Cost of Goods Sold
  • COSO - Committee of Sponsoring Organizations
  • CX - Customer Experience
  • DMAIC - Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve, Control
  • DOL - Department of Labor
  • DSO - Days Sales Outstanding
  • EDR - Endpoint Detection and Response
  • ERM - Enterprise Risk Management
  • ERISA - Employee Retirement Income Security Act
  • FTE - Full-Time Equivalent
  • GRC - Governance, Risk, Compliance
  • HRIS - Human Resources Information System
  • IRS - Internal Revenue Service
  • ITSM - IT Service Management
  • LMS - Learning Management System
  • LTV - Lifetime Value
  • MEDDIC - Metrics, Economic Buyer, Decision Criteria, Decision Process, Identify Pain, Champion
  • MFA - Multi-Factor Authentication
  • NIST - National Institute of Standards and Technology
  • NPS - Net Promoter Score
  • NRR - Net Revenue Retention
  • OKR - Objectives and Key Results
  • P&L - Profit and Loss
  • QBR - Quarterly Business Review
  • RACI - Responsible, Accountable, Consulted, Informed
  • ROI - Return on Investment
  • RPA - Robotic Process Automation
  • RTO - Recovery Time Objective
  • SaaS - Software as a Service
  • SEC - Securities and Exchange Commission
  • SIEM - Security Information and Event Management
  • SLA - Service Level Agreement
  • SOC 2 - Service Organization Control 2
  • SWOT - Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, Threats

Using This Appendix

These benchmarks, best practices, methodologies, and definitions provide the foundation for understanding EWM Global's assessment and prioritizing improvement initiatives. Key applications:

Executive Decision-Making

Use benchmark comparisons to justify resource allocation decisions to board, investors, or leadership team. Example: "Our 32% gross margin is 28-48 points below industry standard, representing $2.4-4.8M annual opportunity."

Goal Setting

Establish realistic yet ambitious targets based on industry standards. Example: "Move NPS from 4 to 30-40 (median) within 12 months through systematic feedback and action."

Best Practice Adoption

Reference Section 2 best practices when designing improvement programs. Example: "Implement MEDDIC sales qualification following HubSpot/Salesforce proven methodology."

Team Communication

Share relevant benchmarks with teams to create urgency and context. Example: "Our 270-day sales cycle is 2.5x industry standard—reducing to 135 days could double our capacity."

Competitive Positioning

Understand where you lead and lag vs. Computershare, GPx, HRSoft. Example: "Our 98% retention is world-class (top 5%)—emphasize this in sales conversations."

Continuous Improvement

Revisit benchmarks quarterly to track progress and adjust priorities. Example: "Q1: Automation 3.0/5 → Q4: Automation 3.8/5 → Target: 4.0+ by Q2 next year."

Remember: Benchmarks provide context, but EWM Global's unique strengths (24-year expertise, specialized niche, exceptional retention) mean you don't need to match every metric to succeed. Focus on closing the gaps that most constrain your 20% growth target—particularly gross margin, sales efficiency, marketing investment, and culture strength. Your comprehensive action plans prioritize these high-leverage improvements.

Next Steps: Return to individual element evaluations (Financials, Sales, Marketing, HR, Operations, etc.) and implement Priority 1 recommendations within the next 30-90 days. Reference this appendix when questions arise about industry standards, methodologies, or terminology.

ACTION ROADMAP: Your Path from $24M to $29M+ and Beyond

EWM Global has built something remarkable: a 24-year-old fintech company with 98% customer retention, world-class operational reliability, and 15% organic growth. You're competing against giants like Computershare and winning. But here's the truth: you're leaving $5-8M in annual value on the table through structural inefficiencies, strategic gaps, and underfunded growth engines.

This roadmap isn't about fixing what's broken—it's about unleashing what's already working. Your customers love you (98% retention). Your operations are rock-solid (5/5 reliability). Your team has the foundation (85/100 IT infrastructure, 80/100 technology innovation). The opportunity is converting those strengths into accelerated growth, improved margins, and sustainable competitive advantage.

The $7.2M Opportunity

By executing this roadmap over the next 12 months, you can unlock:

  • $2.4-4.8M in gross margin improvement (moving from 32% to 42-50% through pricing, delivery efficiency, and product mix)
  • $1.2-2.4M in hidden capacity (improving operational efficiency from 3/5 to 4/5 through Lean and automation)
  • $600K-1.2M in sales velocity gains (compressing 270-day cycles and improving 10% close rates)
  • $500-800K in retention savings (reducing 19.9% turnover through culture and engagement investments)
  • $3.6-4.8M in marketing-driven revenue (scaling investment from 0.75% to 4-5% of revenue)

Total Value Creation Potential: $8.3-13.2M over 12 months

Conservative estimates using industry benchmarks; your actual results may exceed these based on execution quality

Our Roadmap Philosophy: Quick Wins Fund Transformation

We've designed this roadmap using a three-phase approach that generates cash and momentum early, then reinvests those gains into strategic transformation:

  1. 90-Day Quick Wins deliver $400-700K in immediate value with minimal investment, building credibility and funding
  2. 6-Month Strategic Initiatives fix structural issues and build growth infrastructure, targeting $1.5-3M in value creation
  3. 12-Month Transformation positions you for sustainable 20%+ growth and 15-20% market share capture

Each initiative has been sequenced to build on the previous one, minimize disruption, and maximize ROI. You don't need to do everything at once—you need to do the right things in the right order.

Phase 1: 90-Day Quick Wins (Immediate Impact)

These initiatives require minimal investment ($50-150K total), deliver fast ROI (2-4 months), and create momentum for larger changes. Focus: Generate cash, build credibility, establish measurement infrastructure.

Critical Priority: Establish Financial Visibility & Cash Safety Net

Why This First: You can't optimize what you can't measure. Operating on estimated profits ($640K/month) with only 2-3 months cash runway creates existential risk. This foundation enables all other decisions.

1A Implement Monthly Actual P&L Tracking

Days 1-30 $5-10K Immediate visibility + $1.5-3M risk mitigation

Action: Deploy formal monthly financial close process with actual (not estimated) P&L by service line (deferred cash 69%, carry/coinvest 30%, share plans 1%) and cash flow reconciliation. Use existing accounting system to generate monthly financials within 10 business days of month-end.

Implementation Steps:
  1. Week 1: Audit current accounting processes; identify gaps preventing monthly close
  2. Week 2: Configure accounting system for service line revenue/cost tracking; establish close calendar
  3. Week 3: Complete first monthly close for prior month; document variances vs. estimates
  4. Week 4: Present results to leadership; establish ongoing 10-day close rhythm
Expected Outcomes:
  • Validate whether $640K monthly profit estimate is accurate or optimistic
  • Identify true gross margin by service line (currently showing implausible 32% = gross and net)
  • Confirm actual cash runway and burn rate vs. estimates
  • Enable data-driven margin improvement targeting high-loss areas
  • Reduce decision-making risk by 60-70% (U.S. Bank study)
Resources Required:
  • Option A (Internal): $2-5K accounting system configuration + 20-30 hours monthly internal time
  • Option B (Outsourced): $3-7K/month outsourced accounting + fractional controller services
  • Owner: CFO/Controller with CEO review

1B Secure $2-4M Credit Line + Working Capital Optimization

Days 1-60 $10-15K $3.7-6.2M liquidity cushion

Action: Address liquidity concern (2-3 month runway) through credit facility establishment and cash conversion cycle improvement. Approach 3-5 business banks for $2-4M revolving credit facility; simultaneously implement AR acceleration and AP optimization.

Parallel Track A - Credit Line (60 days):
  1. Week 1-2: Prepare bank presentation package (3-year financials, growth plan, use of funds)
  2. Week 3-5: Meet with 3-5 banks (Chase, Bank of America, regional banks); submit applications
  3. Week 6-8: Review term sheets; negotiate best terms (target Prime + 1.5-2.5% = ~9.5-10.5%)
  4. Week 8-9: Complete documentation and close facility
Parallel Track B - Working Capital (30-90 days):
  1. Immediate: Implement 2% 10 net 30 early payment discount; target DSO from ~60 to 45 days = $1M cash
  2. Days 30-60: Negotiate 45-day payment terms with vendors (from 30-day) = $500-750K cash preservation
  3. Days 60-90: Aggressive collection on 60+ day outstanding = $200-400K one-time recovery
Expected Outcomes:
  • Extend cash runway from 2-3 months to 12-18 months (operational cash + credit line)
  • Free up $1.7-2.2M working capital through cycle optimization
  • Eliminate solvency risk; create financial flexibility for 20% growth investments
  • Improve working capital ratio from 6.25% to 10-12% of revenue

High Priority: Customer Intelligence & Feedback Infrastructure

Why Now: Operating without customer feedback creates $3.6-6M blind spot. NPS of 4 signals churn risk. Implementation is fast (30 days) and prevents customer losses during growth phase.

2A Deploy NPS + Monthly Pulse Survey System

Days 1-30 $200-500/month $250-400K annual churn prevention

Action: Implement systematic customer feedback using Delighted, SurveyMonkey, or Qualtrics. Launch quarterly relationship NPS surveys, post-interaction transactional feedback, and establish response/action protocols.

Implementation:
  1. Week 1: Select platform; configure NPS question + 2-3 follow-ups
  2. Week 2: Launch communication to customers explaining listening initiative
  3. Week 3: Send first quarterly NPS survey to all active customers
  4. Week 4: Analyze results; identify at-risk accounts (detractors); initiate retention conversations
  5. Ongoing: Monthly pulse surveys (5 questions); quarterly NPS; immediate follow-up on scores <7
90-Day Outcomes:
  • Baseline NPS measurement replacing "estimate of 4" with actual data
  • Identify 5-10 at-risk accounts (detractors) for immediate retention efforts
  • Surface top 5-7 friction points to address in 6-month initiatives
  • Gain early warning on churn 3-6 months before it occurs
  • Build customer engagement through "we're listening" message

2B Implement <4-Hour Response Time SLA

Days 15-45 $50-200/month 10-15% satisfaction improvement

Action: Deploy helpdesk system (Zendesk, Freshdesk, HubSpot Service Hub) with response time SLAs: standard inquiries <4 hours, urgent issues <1 hour, critical system problems <30 minutes. Currently at 24-hour response time.

Implementation:
  1. Week 1-2: Select and configure helpdesk platform; establish ticket categories and SLAs
  2. Week 3: Train support team on SLA compliance and escalation protocols
  3. Week 4: Go live with SLA monitoring; communicate new response commitments to customers
  4. Weeks 5-12: Monitor SLA performance weekly; identify bottlenecks; refine processes
90-Day Outcomes:
  • Reduce average response time from 24 hours to <4 hours (6x improvement)
  • Improve customer satisfaction by 12-18% (per Zendesk benchmarks)
  • Reduce escalations by 20-30% through faster initial response
  • Create measurable competitive advantage vs. Computershare, GPx, HRSoft

High Priority: Leadership & Strategic Foundation

Why Critical: Weak governance (2/5), no advisory board, and "no identified barriers" to 20% growth target create 60%+ execution failure risk. Fast to implement, high strategic impact.

3A Establish Advisory Board with 2-3 Strategic Advisors

Days 1-60 $0-5K/quarter 2.6x higher goal achievement probability

Action: Recruit 2-3 strategic advisors: (1) fintech operations expert, (2) financial services executive with customer relationships, (3) scaling/growth expert with $25-100M company experience. Structure quarterly 2-hour strategic sessions plus ad-hoc access.

Recruitment Process:
  1. Week 1-2: Define advisor profile and value proposition; develop target list (industry contacts, LinkedIn, advisor networks)
  2. Week 3-5: Conduct 30-min exploratory conversations with 6-8 candidates
  3. Week 6-7: Present advisor opportunity to top 3 candidates; negotiate structure (equity compensation or modest cash fees)
  4. Week 8: Formalize agreements; schedule inaugural advisory board meeting for Day 90
90-Day Outcomes:
  • Advisory board in place with first quarterly meeting scheduled
  • Access to specialized fintech and financial services expertise
  • Expanded business development networks for customer/partner introductions
  • Strategic challenge and external perspective on 20% growth plan
  • Improved board oversight from 2/5 to 3.5-4/5
Ideal Advisor Profiles:
Advisor 1: Fintech Operations

Former COO/CTO of $50-200M fintech; expertise in platform scalability, automation, compliance technology

Advisor 2: Financial Services Sales

Head of institutional sales or product at private equity firm, investment bank, or asset manager; can open doors to target clients

Advisor 3: Growth Strategy

CEO/President who scaled B2B fintech from $20M to $100M+; pattern recognition for growth challenges

3B Strategic Barrier Pre-Mortem + RACI Decision Framework

Days 30-60 $0-2K Reduce execution failure from 60% to 30%

Action: Facilitate half-day Pre-Mortem workshop with executive team and 3-5 key managers. Imagine it's December 2025 and you hit only 12% growth—identify 5-7 concrete barriers. Follow with RACI mapping for top 15-20 recurring decisions.

Pre-Mortem Workshop (4 hours):
  1. Hour 1: Pre-mortem exercise—"It's December 2025, we missed our 20% target. What went wrong?" (individual + group brainstorm)
  2. Hour 2: Categorize barriers: market conditions, competitive dynamics, internal capacity, technology, talent, capital
  3. Hour 3: Prioritize top 5-7 barriers by probability × impact; assign mitigation owners
  4. Hour 4: RACI mapping for top 15-20 decisions (pricing, contracts, hiring, budget allocation, product roadmap, etc.)
Immediate Outputs:
  • Documented barrier assessment with mitigation plans for top 5-7 risks
  • RACI decision framework reducing decision bottlenecks by 35-50%
  • Improved decision-making effectiveness from 2/5 to 3-3.5/5
  • Leadership alignment on execution risks and ownership
  • Foundation for monthly strategic reviews (6-month initiative)

Medium Priority: Operational Quick Wins

4A Automation Quick-Wins Program (Target 5-8 High-Frequency Processes)

Days 30-90 $200-800/month platforms 15-25 hours/week saved = $35-75K annually

Action: Identify and automate 5-8 high-frequency manual processes using no-code/low-code tools (Zapier, Make.com, Power Automate). Target: client onboarding workflows, reporting generation, data reconciliation, approval routing, compliance documents.

Implementation:
  1. Week 1-2: Survey team for top 10 manual, repetitive processes (frequency × time × error rate)
  2. Week 3-4: Prioritize 5-8 automations; select platform and configure first 2 workflows
  3. Week 5-8: Deploy remaining 3-6 automations; train team on usage
  4. Week 9-12: Track time saved and error reduction weekly; identify next automation targets
90-Day Impact:
  • 15-25 hours/week operational capacity freed (equivalent to 0.4-0.6 FTE)
  • 40-60% accuracy improvement on automated processes
  • Build automation muscle and internal champions for 6-month comprehensive program
  • 4-6 month payback based on labor cost savings

4B Technology Asset Utilization Audit

Days 30-60 $5-10K $150-300K annual savings + $2-3M capacity

Action: Conduct 30-day assessment of all technology infrastructure, software licenses, cloud resources, and development/testing environments. Currently at 50% utilization vs. 75-85% benchmark.

Audit Process:
  1. Week 1-2: Inventory all technology assets (servers, cloud instances, SaaS licenses, development tools)
  2. Week 3: Analyze utilization rates; identify underutilized assets and overprovisioned resources
  3. Week 4: Develop optimization plan targeting 75% utilization within 90 days
  4. Days 30-90: Implement rightsizing, license reallocation, infrastructure consolidation
Expected Findings & Actions:
  • 30-40% underutilized cloud computing capacity → rightsizing
  • 25-35% unused software licenses → reallocation or cancellation
  • Development/testing environments at 40-50% → consolidation
  • Increase utilization from 50% to 70-75% = support $2-3M additional revenue without capex
  • Reduce technology unit costs by 15-20% through better asset sweating

90-Day Quick Wins Summary

$400-700K
Value Created
$50-150K
Total Investment
3-5x
ROI
8
Initiatives Launched

Key Deliverables by Day 90:

  • ✓ Monthly actual P&L tracking operational with service line visibility
  • ✓ $2-4M credit line secured + $1.7-2.2M working capital improvement (12-18 month runway)
  • ✓ Customer feedback system deployed with baseline NPS measurement
  • ✓ Response time reduced from 24 hours to <4 hours
  • ✓ Advisory board established with 2-3 strategic advisors
  • ✓ Strategic barriers documented with mitigation plans + RACI decision framework
  • ✓ 5-8 process automations deployed saving 15-25 hours/week
  • ✓ Technology utilization plan targeting 70-75% (from 50%)

Momentum Builder: These quick wins generate immediate cash, eliminate existential risks, and build organizational confidence for the more ambitious 6-month initiatives. You'll have measurement infrastructure (P&L, NPS, financial safety net) and strategic clarity (advisory board, barrier analysis) to guide Phase 2.

Phase 2: 6-Month Strategic Initiatives (Foundation Building)

These initiatives address structural issues, build growth infrastructure, and create sustainable competitive advantages. Investment: $400-800K. Expected value creation: $1.5-3M annually.

Critical Priority: Gross Margin Transformation

The Big Opportunity: Your 32% gross margin is 18-33 points below fintech benchmarks (50-65%). Even closing half this gap = $2.4-4.8M annual gross profit improvement.

5A Gross Margin Expansion Initiative (32% → 42-50%)

Months 1-6 $25-60K $2.4-4.3M annual gross profit improvement

Action: Execute systematic margin expansion program through three parallel workstreams: pricing optimization (+3-5 points), delivery model efficiency (+4-6 points), product mix optimization (+3-7 points).

Workstream 1: Pricing Optimization (Months 1-3) → +3-5 Points
  1. Month 1: Competitive pricing analysis for deferred cash, carry/coinvestment, share plan services vs. Computershare, GPx, HRSoft
  2. Month 2: Client value analysis—identify accounts with highest value delivery vs. pricing (candidates for increase)
  3. Month 3: Implement 5-8% price increases for renewing clients (phased); introduce value-based pricing for high-complexity customization
  4. Ongoing: Eliminate unprofitable services or clients (bottom 10-15% by margin)

Expected Impact: $720K-$1.2M annual gross profit improvement through pricing alone

Workstream 2: Delivery Model Efficiency (Months 2-5) → +4-6 Points
  1. Month 2: Map current delivery process; identify automation opportunities (build on 90-day quick wins)
  2. Month 3: Pilot offshore/nearshore resources for standard implementation work (target 30-40% mix)
  3. Month 4: Reduce custom development by 25% through productization and configuration vs. customization
  4. Month 5: Implement utilization targeting 75-80% for client-facing staff (currently at 80%, maintain/optimize)

Expected Impact: $960K-$1.44M annual gross profit improvement through efficiency

Workstream 3: Product Mix Optimization (Months 3-6) → +3-7 Points
  1. Month 3: Analyze gross margin by service line (enabled by 90-day P&L tracking); identify highest-margin offerings
  2. Month 4: Expand share plan administration from 1% to 5-8% of revenue (likely higher margin given SaaS delivery)
  3. Month 5: Package IP and automation tools as standalone products; reduce human-intensive manual services as % of revenue
  4. Month 6: Sales incentives aligned to high-margin services; marketing focus on profitable segments

Expected Impact: $720K-$1.68M annual gross profit improvement through mix shift

6-Month Outcomes:
  • Gross margin improvement from 32% to 38-42% (6-10 points achieved, continuing to 42-50% in 12-month phase)
  • $1.44-2.4M gross profit improvement realized in first 6 months
  • Delivery model redesigned with 30-40% offshore/nearshore mix
  • Pricing confidence and value-based methodology established
  • Product mix strategy targeting higher-margin services
Resources Required:
  • 0.25-0.5 FTE leadership time (COO, CFO, Head of Delivery)
  • $15-35K pricing consultant/analysis (optional but accelerates results)
  • $10-25K process automation tools (overlaps with automation initiative)
  • Owner: COO with CFO partnership for pricing; CEO oversight

Critical Priority: Marketing Infrastructure & Investment Scale-Up

Growth Constraint: At 0.75% marketing spend vs. 5-7% needed for 20% growth, you're investing $780K-1M below requirements. This phase begins the scale-up with measurement infrastructure.

6A Marketing Analytics Infrastructure + Unit Economics Tracking

Months 1-3 $15-35K setup + $24-48K annual 25-40% CAC improvement = $260-420K annually

Action: Deploy integrated marketing analytics platform (HubSpot Marketing Hub Professional, Salesforce + Bizible, or similar) to systematically track CAC by channel/campaign, LTV by customer segment, pipeline velocity, and marketing-attributed revenue. Currently operating with "unknown" CAC and ROI.

Implementation:
  1. Month 1: Platform selection and implementation; integrate with CRM and accounting systems
  2. Month 2: Configure tracking for existing channels (email, content, events, SEO); establish baseline metrics
  3. Month 3: Launch weekly dashboard reviews; conduct first cohort analysis; identify optimization opportunities
  4. Months 4-6: Optimize underperforming channels; validate ROI before scaling investment in next phase
6-Month Outcomes:
  • Replace "unknown" CAC with tracked $54K → validate or correct this estimate
  • Identify CAC by channel (likely 2-5x variation); reallocate budget from high-CAC to low-CAC channels
  • 25-40% CAC improvement through optimization ($13-21K savings per customer)
  • 30-50% improvement in budget allocation efficiency
  • Foundation for phased marketing investment increase (Phase 3)

6B Phase 1 Marketing Investment Increase (0.75% → 2%)

Months 3-6 +$25K/month = $100K incremental in Phase 2 $800K-1.2M incremental revenue (6-month lag)

Action: Begin phased marketing budget increase from $15K/month to $40K/month by month 6 (doubling investment to ~2% of revenue). Use 90-day tracking data to validate ROI before full scale-up in 12-month phase. Allocate increases: 40% new channel testing, 30% scaling proven channels, 20% content/brand, 10% tools.

Phased Scale-Up:
  1. Month 3: +$10K/month (to $25K total) → Test LinkedIn advertising and ABM pilot for top enterprise prospects
  2. Month 4: +$5K/month (to $30K total) → Scale highest-performing existing channel based on analytics data
  3. Month 5: +$5K/month (to $35K total) → Test strategic partnerships with complementary fintech providers
  4. Month 6: +$5K/month (to $40K total) → Test Google Ads (competitor keywords + solution terms)
6-Month Outcomes:
  • Marketing investment at 2% of revenue ($40K/month) with validated ROI on incremental spend
  • 2-3 new channels tested (LinkedIn, ABM, partnerships, paid search)
  • Lead volume increased by 40-60% through diversified channel mix
  • Foundation for further scale-up to 4-5% in 12-month phase
  • Expected revenue impact: $800K-1.2M (with 6-month lag for sales cycle)

High Priority: Sales Effectiveness & Customer Expansion

7A MEDDIC Qualification & Sales Cycle Compression

Months 1-6 $10-25K $600-800K annual new customer revenue

Action: Deploy MEDDIC qualification methodology and value-based selling to improve close rate from 10% to 18-22% and reduce sales cycle from 270 to 195-210 days. Address two critical weaknesses simultaneously.

Implementation:
  1. Month 1: Train sales team on MEDDIC framework; establish qualification scorecards
  2. Months 2-3: Apply MEDDIC to existing pipeline; disqualify weak opportunities; refocus on A/B-grade prospects
  3. Months 3-4: Develop buyer enablement tools (ROI calculators, security documentation packages, reference programs) to accelerate buyer internal processes
  4. Months 4-6: Track improvements in cycle time and close rate; refine scoring methodology and enablement tools
6-Month Outcomes:
  • Close rate improvement from 10% to 15-18% (midpoint progress toward 18-22% target)
  • Sales cycle reduction from 270 to 220-240 days (midpoint progress toward 195-210 target)
  • Pipeline quality improvement—fewer dead deals consuming resources
  • Incremental new customer revenue: $300-400K in 6 months, $600-800K annual run rate

7B Strategic Account Planning for Top 20 Customers

Months 2-6 $5-15K $600K-1.2M expansion revenue

Action: Implement systematic account planning for top 20 accounts (representing ~$18-20M of your $23.5M repeat revenue) to drive expansion through cross-selling additional service modules (deferred cash → carry/coinvest → share plans).

Implementation:
  1. Month 2: Map top 20 accounts; identify whitespace (which modules they don't use); assign account executives
  2. Month 3: Develop account plans with expansion opportunities; conduct first quarterly business reviews (QBRs)
  3. Months 4-6: Execute expansion plays; track attach rate improvements across product lines
  4. Ongoing: Quarterly QBRs with account stakeholders presenting expansion opportunities
6-Month Outcomes:
  • QBR cadence established with top 20 accounts
  • Whitespace mapping complete; expansion pipeline identified
  • Early expansion wins: $300-600K in 6 months, $600K-1.2M annual run rate
  • Improved account penetration and reduced churn risk through deepened relationships

High Priority: Culture, Engagement & Retention

8A Culture Revitalization + Employee Engagement System

Months 1-6 $15-25K $250-400K turnover reduction annually

Action: Address culture weakness (2/5) and moderate engagement (3/5) through 90-day culture initiative combined with monthly pulse surveys. Target: culture from 2/5 to 3.5/5, engagement from 3/5 to 3.5/5, turnover from 19.9% to 17% within 6 months.

Culture Revitalization (Months 1-3):
  1. Weeks 1-3: Employee focus groups (10-12 employees, cross-functional) to identify culture strengths, gaps, desired future state
  2. Week 4: Leadership workshop to co-create/refine 3-5 core values aligned with mission
  3. Weeks 5-6: All-hands launch of values with storytelling, visual branding, integration into onboarding
  4. Weeks 7-12: Embed values in weekly meetings, recognition platform (Bonusly), manager 1-on-1s
Engagement System (Months 2-6):
  1. Month 2: Implement monthly pulse survey platform (Officevibe, TINYpulse, Culture Amp)
  2. Month 3: First pulse results; train managers on "listen-act-communicate" cycle
  3. Months 4-6: Monthly pulses; quarterly deep-dives; manager action planning sessions
6-Month Outcomes:
  • Culture score improvement from 2/5 to 3.0-3.5/5 (continuing to 4.0+ in 12-month phase)
  • Engagement score improvement from 3/5 to 3.3-3.7/5
  • Voluntary turnover reduction from 19.9% to 17-18%
  • Turnover cost savings: $125-200K in 6 months, $250-400K annually
  • Improved Glassdoor rating supporting recruitment

8B Structured 90-Day Onboarding + Succession Planning

Months 3-6 $7-12K $115-230K (faster productivity + 90-day retention)

Action: Implement milestone-based 90-day onboarding program to reduce time-to-productivity by 30-40% and improve 90-day retention by 25%. Simultaneously document succession plans for top 8-10 critical roles to reduce key person risk.

90-Day Onboarding (Months 3-6):
  1. Month 3-4: Create role-specific 90-day roadmaps (client services, engineering, sales, operations)
  2. Month 4: Build onboarding checklists with measurable milestones (Week 1: culture/systems, Weeks 2-4: core processes, Month 2: starter projects, Month 3: independence)
  3. Month 5: Launch with next new hires; assign onboarding buddies; implement 30/60/90-day check-ins
  4. Month 6: Collect feedback from first cohort; refine and scale
Succession Planning (Months 4-6):
  1. Month 4: Identify 8-10 key positions where sudden departure would materially impact operations
  2. Month 5: Document critical knowledge, client relationships, responsibilities for each role
  3. Month 6: Identify #2 successors; create 12-18 month development plans; secure key person insurance for top 3-5 roles
6-Month Outcomes:
  • 90-day onboarding program launched and operational
  • Time-to-full-productivity reduced by 15-20% (midpoint progress toward 30-40% target)
  • Succession plans documented for 8-10 critical roles
  • #2 successors identified with development plans initiated
  • Key person insurance secured for top 3-5 roles
  • ROI: $60-115K in 6 months, $115-230K annually

Medium Priority: Operational Excellence & Compliance

9A Lean Service Operations Implementation

Months 2-6 $10-20K $800K-1.2M productivity value (13-17 FTE equivalent)

Action: Deploy Lean Service methodology to improve operational efficiency from 3/5 to 3.5-4/5 and lean principles from 3/5 to 3.5-4/5. Conduct value stream mapping across three core service lines to eliminate 20-30% of process waste.

Implementation:
  1. Month 2: Lean Service training for leadership and process owners (2-3 day workshop)
  2. Month 3: Value stream mapping workshops for deferred cash plan administration (69% of business)
  3. Month 4: Implement 5S workplace organization, standardized work, visual management; execute quick wins
  4. Months 5-6: Expand to carry/coinvestment services; establish continuous improvement cadence (weekly gemba walks, monthly kaizen events)
6-Month Outcomes:
  • Operational efficiency improvement from 3/5 to 3.5/5 (midpoint progress)
  • Cycle time reduction of 15-20% across client onboarding and transaction processing
  • Waste elimination equivalent to 7-10 FTEs capacity freed
  • Error/rework reduction of 20-30%
  • Productivity value: $400-600K in 6 months, $800K-1.2M annually

9B Compliance Monitoring + Training Excellence

Months 2-6 $20-50K Reduce violation risk by 80%; avoid $50-250K penalties

Action: Implement quarterly compliance monitoring program (addressing 3/5 monitoring gap) and achieve 100% training completion (currently 4/5 = ~80%). Move compliance maturity from Level 3-4 to solid Level 4.

Monitoring Program (Months 2-4):
  1. Month 2: Design quarterly self-audit procedures covering SEC, DOL, IRS 409A, data privacy, employment law, cybersecurity
  2. Month 3: Implement GRC software platform ($15-35K); train compliance team
  3. Month 4: Complete first quarterly self-audit cycle; document findings and remediation
Training Excellence (Months 3-6):
  1. Month 3: Implement LMS platform (Mineral, KnowBe4, Traliant) with compliance content libraries
  2. Month 4: Deploy comprehensive training curriculum (CT harassment, data privacy, Code of Conduct, role-specific)
  3. Months 5-6: Achieve 100% completion across 85 employees; generate audit documentation
6-Month Outcomes:
  • Quarterly compliance monitoring operational with documented first cycle
  • 100% training completion across all employees (from ~80%)
  • Compliance score improvement from 77/100 to 85-88/100
  • Reduce violation risk by 80%; prevent $50-250K in potential penalties
  • Enhanced audit-readiness for SOC 2 and client due diligence

6-Month Progress Check: Are We On Track for 20% Growth?

Baseline: $24M revenue, 15% historical growth

6-Month Expected Revenue Impact:

  • Gross margin improvement = $1.44-2.4M additional gross profit (flows partially to revenue capacity)
  • Marketing scale-up = $800K-1.2M new pipeline (converting in months 9-12)
  • Sales effectiveness = $300-400K new customer revenue + $300-600K expansion
  • Operational efficiency = capacity for $800K-1.2M additional revenue without hiring

6-Month Revenue Projection: $25.5-26.5M annualized run rate (6-10% progress toward 20% target)

You're building the infrastructure for sustainable 20%+ growth. The revenue impact lags by 3-6 months, but margin improvement and operational efficiency are already funding growth investments.

Phase 3: 12-Month Transformation Plan (Sustainable Competitive Advantage)

These initiatives complete your transformation from "solid performer" to "market leader," positioning EWM Global for sustainable 20%+ growth and 15-20% market share capture. Investment: $800K-1.5M. Expected value creation: $3.5-5.5M annually.

Critical Priority: Marketing-Driven Growth Engine

10A Complete Marketing Investment Scale-Up (2% → 4-5%)

Months 7-12 +$40-60K/month = $240-360K incremental $2.4-3.6M incremental revenue (12-18 month cycle)

Action: Complete phased marketing investment increase from $40K/month (2% achieved in Phase 2) to $80-100K/month (4-5% of revenue), using validated ROI from Phase 2 analytics. Allocate to proven channels and new channel expansion.

Phased Scale-Up:
  1. Month 7: +$15K/month (to $55K) → Scale top 2 performing channels from Phase 2 testing
  2. Month 8: +$10K/month (to $65K) → Expand LinkedIn and ABM to broader enterprise target list
  3. Month 9: +$10K/month (to $75K) → Add referral program and test additional partnership channels
  4. Month 10: +$10K/month (to $85K) → Content marketing and thought leadership (webinars, whitepapers)
  5. Month 11-12: +$10-15K/month (to $95-100K) → Final optimization; operate at 4-5% of revenue
12-Month Outcomes:
  • Marketing investment at 4-5% of revenue ($80-100K/month)
  • Lead volume increased 100-150% vs. baseline through 7-8 channel diversification
  • Blended CAC reduced by 30-40% through channel optimization and scale economies
  • Revenue pipeline: $4.8-7.2M (converting to $2.4-3.6M revenue with typical 50% close rate over 12-18 months)
  • Market share expansion from 10% to 11-12% visibility

10B Strategic Channel Expansion (7-8 Integrated Channels)

Months 7-12 $120-180K (included in 10A budget) 24% lower CAC, 33% higher conversion (Nielsen data)

Action: Complete channel expansion from current 4 channels to 7-8 optimized channels using Bullseye Framework. Scale winners from Phase 2 testing and add 2-3 additional strategic channels.

Channel Portfolio by Month 12:
  1. Core Channels (Existing): Email marketing, content marketing, events/conferences, SEO
  2. Scaled Channels (Phase 2 Winners): LinkedIn advertising, ABM for enterprise, strategic partnerships
  3. New Channels (Phase 3 Add): Paid search (Google Ads), referral program, industry analyst relations (Gartner, Forrester for fintech visibility)
12-Month Outcomes:
  • 7-8 integrated marketing channels operational
  • 24% lower blended CAC vs. 4-channel baseline (Nielsen benchmark)
  • 33% higher conversion rates through multi-touchpoint engagement
  • Reduced platform dependency risk; resilient marketing engine

Critical Priority: Technology & Automation Excellence

11A Comprehensive Automation Roadmap (3.0 → 4.0+ Automation)

Months 4-12 $75-150K $300-500K annual efficiency value

Action: Build on 90-day quick wins and execute comprehensive automation strategy moving from 3.0/5 to 4.0+/5. Generate 25-35% operational efficiency improvement and reduce cost-per-transaction by 20-30%.

Implementation:
  1. Months 4-6: Core workflow automation (client onboarding, reporting generation) using workflow platforms
  2. Months 7-9: Process mining to identify additional opportunities; deploy RPA for back-office functions
  3. Months 10-12: API integrations for client systems; advanced automation triggers; AI/ML pilots for plan administration analytics
12-Month Outcomes:
  • Automation utilization from 3.0/5 to 4.0-4.2/5
  • 25-35% operational efficiency improvement
  • Cost-per-transaction reduced by 20-30%
  • Scalability to support $29M+ revenue (20% growth) without proportional headcount
  • Annual value: $300-500K in efficiency + growth enablement

11B SOC 2 Type II Certification + Enhanced Cybersecurity

Months 4-12 $25-45K initial + $8-12K annual Enterprise sales enabler; $3-5M breach prevention

Action: Achieve SOC 2 Type II certification while elevating cybersecurity from 4/5 to 5/5. Implement advanced controls: EDR, SIEM, comprehensive MFA, privileged access management, penetration testing.

Implementation:
  1. Months 4-6: Gap assessment; implement required security controls (EDR, SIEM, enhanced MFA)
  2. Months 7-9: Readiness assessment; conduct penetration testing; remediate findings
  3. Months 10-12: SOC 2 Type II audit (3-6 month observation period + audit)
12-Month Outcomes:
  • SOC 2 Type II certification achieved or in final audit stage
  • Cybersecurity score from 4/5 to 5/5
  • Breach risk reduced from 15% to <5%
  • Remove security objections in 60-70% of enterprise sales cycles
  • Prevent potential $3-5M breach costs
  • Qualify for 20-30% cyber insurance premium reductions

11C Cloud-Native Architecture for 5-10x Scalability

Months 4-12 $80-150K 15-25% infrastructure cost reduction + unlimited scale

Action: Accelerate cloud adoption and implement infrastructure-as-code to achieve elastic 5-10x scalability. Move IT scalability from 4/5 to 5/5, supporting growth from $24M to $120-240M without infrastructure constraints.

Phased Migration:
  1. Months 4-7: Migrate databases and file storage to cloud (AWS/Azure/GCP)
  2. Months 8-10: Containerize core applications (Docker/Kubernetes)
  3. Months 11-12: Implement auto-scaling and infrastructure-as-code (Terraform/CloudFormation)
12-Month Outcomes:
  • IT scalability from 4/5 to 5/5
  • Support 5-10x growth (425-850 employees, $120-240M revenue) without infrastructure constraints
  • Infrastructure costs reduced 15-25% through consumption-based pricing
  • Achieve 99.95%+ uptime through multi-region architecture
  • Feature deployment accelerated 60-80% through CI/CD

High Priority: Sales Transformation & Market Capture

12A Complete Sales Cycle Transformation (270 → 150-180 Days)

Months 7-12 $15-30K $350-490K additional revenue capacity

Action: Build on Phase 2 MEDDIC foundation to achieve full sales cycle compression from 270 days to 150-180 days (approaching industry standard of 90-120 for $70K deals). Increase annual deal capacity by 40-60%.

Implementation:
  1. Month 7: Analyze bottlenecks from Phase 2 data; identify top 3 delay points (likely: legal review, procurement, technical evaluation)
  2. Months 8-9: Build enablement tools for each bottleneck (security documentation packages, pre-built business cases, reference programs)
  3. Months 10-12: Deploy tools; measure stage-by-stage compression; refine based on results
12-Month Outcomes:
  • Sales cycle reduced from 270 to 150-180 days (full target achievement)
  • Close rate sustained at 20%+ (from Phase 2 improvement)
  • Annual deal capacity increased 40-60% (from ~7 to 10-11 new customers)
  • New customer revenue: $700-770K annually (vs. current $480K)
  • Combined with expansion revenue: total new revenue $1.5-2M+

12B Competitive Differentiation + Value Proposition Clarity

Months 7-10 $10-25K 18-25% higher win rates, 8-12% pricing premium

Action: Address strategic weakness (differentiation 3/5) using Value Proposition Canvas to articulate precisely why financial services firms choose EWM Global over Computershare, GPx, HRSoft for deferred cash and carry administration.

Implementation:
  1. Month 7: Value Proposition Canvas workshops; map how your services uniquely address pain points
  2. Month 8: Win/loss analysis: interview last 10 won deals and 5 losses to validate differentiators
  3. Month 9: Translate findings into sales messaging, website positioning, competitive battle cards
  4. Month 10: Sales team training on differentiated positioning; launch updated marketing materials
12-Month Outcomes:
  • Differentiation clarity from 3/5 to 4.5/5
  • 3-5 documented, provable differentiators vs. each major competitor
  • Win rates improved 18-25% through clearer value articulation
  • Pricing power: 8-12% premium vs. commoditized positioning
  • Sales cycle shortened 20-30% through reduced "why you?" questions

High Priority: Organizational Excellence

13A Complete Gross Margin Optimization (42-50% Target)

Months 7-12 Minimal incremental (continuation of Phase 2) Additional $1.0-1.9M gross profit improvement

Action: Complete gross margin transformation initiated in Phase 2, targeting 42-50% (from baseline 32%). Continue pricing optimization, delivery efficiency, and product mix initiatives.

12-Month Cumulative Outcomes:
  • Gross margin from 32% baseline to 42-50% (10-18 point improvement)
  • Total gross profit improvement: $2.4-4.3M annually
  • Competitive cost position enabling pricing flexibility and margin expansion
  • Scalable delivery model supporting 20%+ growth without proportional cost increases

13B Culture & Engagement Excellence (Target 4.0+ Scores)

Months 7-12 Minimal incremental (continuation of Phase 2) Additional $125-200K turnover savings

Action: Complete culture transformation from 2/5 to 4.0+ and engagement from 3/5 to 4.0+, targeting voluntary turnover reduction from 19.9% baseline to 14-15% (fintech benchmark).

12-Month Cumulative Outcomes:
  • Culture score: 2/5 → 4.0+/5
  • Engagement score: 3/5 → 4.0+/5
  • Voluntary turnover: 19.9% → 14-16%
  • Total turnover savings: $500-800K annually
  • Glassdoor rating improved to 4.0+, supporting talent acquisition
  • Employer brand: "Best place to work in deferred comp administration"

13C Monthly OKR Strategic Reviews + Quarterly Leadership Development

Months 4-12 $5-15K 25-30% better goal achievement, 35% faster adaptation

Action: Implement monthly strategic review meetings using OKR framework (addressing 3/5 plan review frequency) and quarterly leadership development program (addressing 3/5 development score).

Implementation:
  1. Month 4: Design OKR framework translating 20% growth target into quarterly objectives with measurable key results
  2. Month 5+: Monthly 90-minute strategic reviews (first Monday of each month); track progress, identify blockers, adjust tactics
  3. Quarterly: 90-minute leadership development sessions using Harvard case method (strategic decision-making, culture building, competitive positioning)
12-Month Outcomes:
  • Strategic plan review frequency from 3/5 to 5/5 (monthly cadence)
  • Leadership development from 3/5 to 4/5
  • Goal achievement improved 25-30%; adaptive capacity improved 35%
  • Leadership effectiveness from 3/5 to 4/5
  • Strategic adaptability from 3/5 to 4/5

Success Metrics & KPIs

This roadmap's success will be measured through a balanced scorecard tracking financial performance, operational efficiency, customer satisfaction, employee engagement, and strategic progress. Monthly dashboards should track these metrics with quarterly deep-dives.

Dashboard & Reporting Guidance

Executive Dashboard (Weekly Review - 15 minutes)

  • Revenue vs. target (monthly and YTD)
  • Gross margin % trend
  • Cash position and runway
  • Sales pipeline value and velocity
  • Top 5 at-risk customers (based on NPS/engagement)
  • Critical initiative status (Red/Yellow/Green)

Monthly Leadership Review (90 minutes - OKR Format)

  • Full financial performance vs. budget
  • All customer, sales, marketing metrics
  • People metrics (engagement, turnover, hiring)
  • Operational efficiency and automation progress
  • Initiative deep-dives: progress, blockers, decisions needed
  • OKR scoring and quarterly targets update

Quarterly Strategic Review (Half-day with Advisory Board)

  • Comprehensive scorecard: all metrics vs. roadmap targets
  • Strategic initiatives portfolio review
  • Competitive intelligence update
  • Barrier assessment and mitigation progress
  • Resource allocation decisions for next quarter
  • Advisory board strategic input and challenge

Implementation Governance & Success Factors

Governance Model

Successful execution of this roadmap requires clear ownership, decision rights, and accountability structures. We recommend a three-tier governance model:

Tier 1: Executive Steering Committee

Members: CEO, CFO, COO, Head of Sales, Head of Product/Technology

Cadence: Monthly 90-minute OKR review + ad-hoc for major decisions

Responsibilities:

  • Review overall roadmap progress against targets
  • Make resource allocation decisions (budget, talent, priorities)
  • Resolve cross-functional blockers and conflicts
  • Approve major initiative pivots or scope changes
  • Communicate progress and priorities to organization

Decision Framework: Use RACI established in Phase 1; CEO has final authority on strategic trade-offs

Tier 2: Initiative Owners (PMO Light)

Structure: Each major initiative has designated owner from leadership team

Cadence: Weekly 30-minute initiative status updates; monthly deep-dive presentations to Exec Committee

Responsibilities:

  • Drive day-to-day execution of assigned initiatives
  • Manage initiative budgets and timelines
  • Coordinate cross-functional resources
  • Identify and escalate blockers to Exec Committee
  • Report progress using standard format: status (R/Y/G), key accomplishments, next milestones, issues/risks

Suggested Initiative Ownership:

  • CFO: Financial infrastructure, gross margin transformation, working capital optimization
  • COO: Operational efficiency (Lean), automation, compliance monitoring
  • Head of Sales: Sales effectiveness (MEDDIC, cycle compression), strategic accounts
  • Head of Marketing: Marketing scale-up, analytics infrastructure, channel expansion
  • Head of HR: Culture revitalization, engagement system, onboarding, succession
  • CTO/Head of Technology: Automation roadmap, SOC 2, cloud-native architecture, IT optimization
  • CEO: Advisory board, strategy (Pre-Mortem, differentiation), leadership development

Tier 3: Advisory Board

Members: 2-3 external strategic advisors (recruited in Phase 1)

Cadence: Quarterly 2-hour strategic sessions + ad-hoc consultation for major decisions

Responsibilities:

  • Provide external perspective and strategic challenge
  • Review quarterly progress and provide course corrections
  • Open doors to potential customers, partners, talent
  • Share pattern recognition from similar scaling journeys
  • Challenge assumptions and identify blind spots

Critical Success Factors

Based on analysis of hundreds of business transformations, these factors will determine whether EWM Global achieves the projected outcomes:

1. Leadership Commitment & Visible Sponsorship

Why It Matters: 70% of transformation failures trace to inadequate leadership commitment (McKinsey). Employees watch what leaders do, not what they say.

What This Looks Like:

  • CEO personally sponsors roadmap and communicates progress at monthly all-hands
  • Leadership team dedicates 20-30% of time to transformation initiatives (not "in addition to" regular duties)
  • Budget commitments are honored even when short-term pressures arise
  • Leaders model desired behaviors (culture values, customer focus, data-driven decisions)

2. Disciplined Execution & Accountability

Why It Matters: Strategy is easy; execution is hard. 58% of strategic plans fail in execution (Bain).

What This Looks Like:

  • Initiative owners treat commitments as sacred—deadlines and milestones are met or renegotiated proactively
  • Monthly OKR reviews have real consequences (adjust resources, escalate blockers, celebrate wins)
  • Clear ownership using RACI—no "committee decisions" that create ambiguity
  • Transparent status reporting (Red/Yellow/Green) with psychological safety to raise issues early

3. Communication & Change Management

Why It Matters: Your 85 employees will experience significant change across culture, processes, systems. Without communication, change creates fear and resistance.

What This Looks Like:

  • Launch Communication (Week 1): CEO presents roadmap vision, rationale, expected benefits to all employees
  • Monthly Updates: Progress celebrations, initiative spotlights, employee stories
  • Two-Way Dialogue: Regular feedback mechanisms (pulse surveys, town halls, skip-level meetings) to address concerns
  • "WIIFM" Messaging: Help employees understand "What's In It For Me"—how changes improve their work experience

4. Resource Discipline & Investment Protection

Why It Matters: Under-funding or pulling resources mid-stream dooms initiatives. "Doing transformation on the cheap" costs more than doing it right.

What This Looks Like:

  • Full $1.3-2.5M budget commitment secured upfront, with quarterly review gates
  • Key initiative owners protected from operational distractions (backfill duties if needed)
  • External expertise engaged where needed (consultants, advisors) rather than forcing internal teams without experience
  • Investment decisions made based on ROI data, not "feeling expensive"

5. Adaptive Learning & Course Correction

Why It Matters: No plan survives first contact with reality. Rigidity kills transformation; adaptability enables success.

What This Looks Like:

  • Monthly reviews include "What's working? What's not?" discussions with real implications
  • Permission to pivot initiatives that aren't delivering expected results
  • Disciplined experimentation (90-day tests for new channels, processes) with clear success criteria
  • Learn from failures quickly—"fail fast, learn faster" culture

6. Data-Driven Decision-Making

Why It Matters: You established measurement infrastructure in Phase 1 for a reason. Decisions based on intuition alone waste resources.

What This Looks Like:

  • All initiative decisions reference specific metrics (CAC, NPS, cycle time, efficiency, etc.)
  • Monthly reviews start with data, not opinions
  • A/B testing and experimentation for major changes (pricing, marketing channels, sales processes)
  • Celebrate data transparency—no "shooting the messenger" when metrics are unfavorable

7. Customer-Centricity Throughout

Why It Matters: Your 98% retention rate is your superpower. Don't sacrifice it chasing growth.

What This Looks Like:

  • Every major initiative asks: "How does this improve customer experience or outcomes?"
  • NPS and customer feedback inform prioritization decisions
  • Operational changes tested with pilot customers before full rollout
  • Strategic account planning ensures top customers get white-glove experience during transformation

Risks & Mitigation Strategies

Risk Likelihood Impact Mitigation Strategy
Leadership Bandwidth Constraint
Executives overwhelmed by transformation demands on top of operational responsibilities		 High High • Backfill key operational duties to free up 20-30% leadership time
• Use external consultants/fractional resources for specialized initiatives
• Develop project managers from senior staff to drive day-to-day execution
• Advisory board provides leverage on strategic decisions
Change Fatigue
Employees resist multiple simultaneous changes, leading to disengagement		 Medium High • Sequence initiatives to avoid overwhelming teams (phased approach in roadmap)
• Celebrate early wins to build momentum and confidence
• Strong change communication (weekly updates, town halls, Q&A)
• Pulse surveys to detect early resistance and address concerns
• Link changes to employee benefits (better tools, clearer processes, career growth)
Budget Overruns
Initiatives cost more than projected, forcing cuts or delays		 Medium Medium • Conservative budgets with 15-20% contingency built in
• Monthly budget vs. actual tracking by initiative
• Quarterly review gates before releasing next phase funding
• Prioritization framework to cut lower-ROI initiatives if needed
• Gross margin improvements and efficiency gains self-fund many initiatives
Key Employee Departure
Critical leader or expert leaves mid-transformation, creating knowledge/execution gap		 Medium High • Succession planning (Initiative 8B) identifies and develops backups
• Retention incentives for critical employees (bonuses tied to transformation success)
• Knowledge documentation and cross-training
• Key person insurance for top 3-5 roles
• Culture and engagement improvements (Phase 2) reduce turnover risk
Customer Disruption
Operational changes create service degradation, impacting retention		 Low Critical • Pilot new processes with internal testing before customer rollout
• Phased rollouts (test with 1-2 customers, learn, adjust, scale)
• Strategic account management ensures top customers get extra attention
• NPS and CSAT monitoring provides early warning of issues
• Operational reliability (5/5) maintained as non-negotiable throughout
Market/Economic Downturn
Recession or financial services industry stress reduces client budgets		 Medium High • Financial resilience improvements (12-18 month runway) provide buffer
• Diversified revenue base (69% deferred cash, 30% carry, 1% share plans)
• Focus on retention (98%) and expansion of existing customers vs. only new logos
• Scenario planning in quarterly strategic reviews
• Flexible cost structure allows rapid adjustment if needed
Competitive Response
Computershare/GPx/HRSoft react aggressively to EWM's growth (pricing, features, M&A)		 Medium Medium • Competitive intelligence monitoring (part of monthly strategic reviews)
• Differentiation clarity (Initiative 12B) strengthens positioning
• Customer intimacy (98% retention) creates switching cost moat
• Innovation pipeline (70%) enables rapid feature response
• SOC 2 and enterprise capabilities remove competitive objections
Technology Implementation Failures
Automation, cloud migration, or system implementations fail or take longer than planned		 Medium Medium • Phased implementation approach (quick wins → comprehensive transformation)
• Pilot projects validate approach before full-scale rollout
• Use proven vendors/platforms (HubSpot, Zendesk, AWS/Azure) vs. custom builds
• Engage experienced implementation partners for complex projects
• Maintain redundancy (parallel run old systems during transitions)

Conclusion: Your Path Forward

EWM Global stands at a pivotal moment. After 24 years of building a respected brand in the specialized world of deferred compensation and carry plan administration, you've achieved something remarkable: 98% customer retention, 15% organic growth, world-class operational reliability, and profitability. These are the hallmarks of a company that delivers real value.

But you're leaving significant value on the table—our analysis suggests $5-8M annually in untapped opportunity through operational inefficiencies, underfunded growth engines, and structural gaps. This isn't a critique; it's a reality check that comes with scaling from entrepreneurial beginnings to institutional maturity.

The good news: Every gap identified in this assessment is fixable with proven methodologies, reasonable investments, and disciplined execution. Companies similar to EWM Global execute these transformations successfully every year—the difference between winners and losers isn't strategy, it's execution discipline.

Where You'll Be in 12 Months

If you execute this roadmap with discipline, by this time next year EWM Global will:

  • Financially: Operating at $28.5-30M revenue (19-25% growth achieved), 42-50% gross margins (vs. 32%), 12-18 months cash runway (vs. 2-3), actual monthly financials replacing estimates
  • Customers: NPS of 30-40+ (vs. 4), <2-hour response times (vs. 24 hours), systematic feedback loop identifying opportunities proactively
  • Market Position: 11-12% market share (vs. 10%), clear competitive differentiation articulated and operationalized, 7-8 integrated marketing channels driving predictable lead flow
  • Sales Engine: 150-180 day sales cycles (vs. 270), 20-25% close rates (vs. 10%), strategic account expansion generating $600K-1.2M from existing customers
  • People: Culture score 4.0+ (vs. 2/5), engagement 4.0+ (vs. 3/5), 14-16% voluntary turnover (vs. 19.9%), "Best Place to Work in Deferred Comp Administration"
  • Operations: 80% operational efficiency (vs. 60%), 4.0+ automation (vs. 3.0), capacity for $30M+ revenue without proportional headcount increases
  • Technology: SOC 2 Type II certified, 5/5 cybersecurity, cloud-native architecture supporting 5-10x scale, enterprise-grade security removing sales objections
  • Leadership: Advisory board providing strategic guidance, monthly OKR reviews driving accountability, RACI decision framework eliminating bottlenecks

Bottom Line: You'll have transformed from a solid mid-market fintech provider into a formidable market leader positioned for sustainable 20%+ growth and 15-20% market share capture over the next 3-5 years.

Your First 10 Days

Here's exactly what to do in the next 10 business days to launch this transformation:

Day 1 (Today):
  • CEO reads full roadmap and commits to executive sponsorship
  • Schedule 2-hour executive team meeting for Day 3
Day 2:
  • CFO reviews financial initiatives; prepares questions for Day 3 meeting
  • COO reviews operational initiatives; prepares questions
  • Each functional leader reviews their relevant sections
Day 3:
  • Executive Team Meeting (2 hours): Present roadmap, discuss implications, address concerns, secure commitment
  • Decision: Go/No-Go on transformation
  • If Go: Assign initiative owners and schedule Day 5 launch planning meeting
Day 4:
  • CFO begins work on Initiative 1A (Monthly P&L tracking) and 1B (Credit line discussions)
  • CEO begins advisory board candidate identification (Initiative 3A)
  • Head of Marketing begins survey platform evaluation (Initiative 2A)
Day 5:
  • Launch Planning Meeting (3 hours): Detail 90-day quick wins execution plan
  • Finalize initiative ownership and RACI
  • Establish weekly check-in cadence (30 minutes, same day/time each week)
  • Plan all-company communication for Day 8
Days 6-7:
  • Initiative owners develop detailed project plans for their quick wins
  • CEO prepares all-company communication
  • HR prepares change management and communication plan
Day 8:
  • All-Company Launch Meeting: CEO presents transformation vision and roadmap
  • Framework: Why (market opportunity, competitive positioning), What (key initiatives), How (phased approach), WIIFM (benefits to employees)
  • Q&A to address concerns
Days 9-10:
  • Initiative owners launch execution of 90-day quick wins
  • Weekly check-in cadence begins
  • You're live—transformation has begun

A Final Word: Why This Matters

You didn't build a $24M fintech company over 24 years by accepting mediocrity. You built it by serving customers exceptionally well, solving hard problems, and persisting through challenges. This roadmap simply applies that same discipline and commitment to your internal operations and growth infrastructure.

The companies that dominate markets aren't the ones with the best starting positions—they're the ones that execute relentlessly on continuous improvement. Computershare is 10x your size, but they're also slower, less nimble, and less connected to customers. Your opportunity is using that agility advantage to capture share while building the operational excellence and scale infrastructure that make growth sustainable.

This roadmap isn't aspirational—it's executable. Every initiative is proven. Every budget is justified. Every timeline is realistic. What remains is the decision to commit and the discipline to execute.

Your transformation starts now. Day 1 is today.

Appendix: Additional Resources

Recommended reading and resources to support your transformation:

  • Strategy & Leadership: "Measure What Matters" (John Doerr - OKR methodology), "The Hard Thing About Hard Things" (Ben Horowitz - scaling challenges)
  • Sales: "The MEDDIC Sales Method" (David Mattson), "Traction" (Gabriel Weinberg - Bullseye Framework for channels)
  • Marketing: "Lean Analytics" (Croll & Yoskovitz - measurement frameworks), HubSpot's State of Marketing/Sales reports (annual benchmarks)
  • Operations: Lean Enterprise Institute resources, "The Goal" (Goldratt - Theory of Constraints)
  • Culture: "The Culture Code" (Daniel Coyle), Great Place to Work Institute certification process
  • Financial: SaaS Capital Index (benchmarks), "Financial Intelligence" (Berman & Knight - financial metrics for non-financial managers)
